text: Empiricism cannot explain observable events because it forbids embedding them in unobservable continuities.
The mind would consist only of disconnected spontaneities if completely described by conscious experience alone.
Conscious events must be embedded within otherwise unconscious psychological continuities to be explained.
The statement that X's parts are governed by laws L is not equivalent to the statement that X itself is governed by those laws.
The statement that X complies with the same laws as Y is not equivalent to the statement that X-internal events are to be explained by the same principles as Y-internal events.
Constitutive dependence is distinct from causal dependence.
Propositions are not identical with sentences.
Facts are distributions or redistributions of mass-energy.
A truth is distinct from the fact in virtue of which it holds.
Events are redistributions of mass-energy.
Properties are non-spatiotemporal entities.
Concepts are non-spatiotemporal.
The physical world is causally closed.
The mental affects the physical, therefore the mental must be physical (ontological materialism).
Explanatory dualism is true even if ontological dualism is false.
There is no way to understand why physicalistic statements being true should entail mentalistic statements being true.
Propositions consist of concepts.
The explanatory generalizations of different disciplines consist of distinct concepts.
Psychology and physiology are more remote from each other than physiology and microphysics.
Psychological propositions do not present the facts in virtue of which they hold as being in physical space.
Perceptions are not given to us as occurring in the same spatial manifold as physical events.
Scientific thought is not the same as empirical thought.
The term "empirical thought" is an oxymoron.
To the extent that thought mediates between observations and beliefs, beliefs are not directly supported by observation.
Most philosophers make heavy concessions to empiricism without empiricism-independent justification.
We do not sense-perceive forces or causal powers.
If empiricism is correct, we cannot know to what degree our sensory experiences are veridical.
If empiricism is correct, the future cannot be known on the basis of the present.
Hume accepted skepticism about perception and induction because they were corollaries of empiricism, instead of rejecting empiricism.
Logical relations hold among propositions, not sentences.
Propositions are non-spatiotemporal.
The spatiotemporal world comprises no instances of logical relations.
Entailment holds if, given P, it is not even a theoretical possibility that Q should fail to be true.
Confirmation holds if, given P, it is ceteris paribus more likely than not that Q is true.
Some philosophers hold that sentences are the relata of logical relations, but this is false.
Some philosophers hold that propositions are spatiotemporal, but this is false.
Properties are constituents of propositions.
Propositions consist of properties.
Formal entailment holds among propositions, not expressions.
Statements that a sentence is "formally true" are abbreviated ways of making statements about propositions.
The view that properties are identical with scattered objects composed of their instances is false.
Two uninstantiated properties would be identical if properties were identical with their instances (reductio).
One can change a scattered object without affecting the corresponding property.
Expression-tokens entail one another only in a derivative sense, via their meanings.
Logical relations hold among meanings, not among expressions per se.
The relata of logical relations must be things that are true or false.
Empiricists treat truth as a one-place relation (property) rather than a multi-place relation.
Empiricist subjectivism about arithmetic reflects inability to countenance non-spatiotemporal entities.
Conventionalization is culture-level subjectivization.
Empiricism mistakenly treats relations as properties.
Empiricism often treats 3-place relations as 2-place relations.
Colors are not purely subjective in the empiricist sense.
Colors are properties of three-place relations.
Color-experiences are informative, not categorically hallucinatory.
Colors are mind-dependent but not mental.
The empiricist puts headaches in the same category as concern for one's child's welfare, but this is false.
Emotions are not merely "sentiments" equivalent to bodily sensations.
Meanings are identical with sets of properties.
Wittgenstein's view that "meaning is use" is false.
If expression-tokens were nothing but bursts of noise, there could be linguistic activity on planets without sentient life (reductio).
Attempts to scientize psychology have typically been attempts to empiricize it.
Freud and Chomsky succeeded in scientizing certain sub-domains of psychology.
There is unconscious ideation.
There is ideation that is not only unconscious but subpersonal.
People can rationalize and deceive themselves.
People can repress knowledge they wish they didn't have.
People can be internally conflicted, and internal conflict is a battle between conscious and unconscious conceits.
Repressed emotions may be expressed as symptoms.
The concept of repression is coherent despite seemingly cogent arguments against it.
A psychopath is someone who doesn't have a conscience and never had one.
A sociopath is someone who had a conscience but ceased to have one.
Sociopathogenesis involves implementing a certain sort of rationalization.
Sociopaths are people who "sell out" and "die inside."
The pre-sociopath has values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasps non-instrumental goodness.
The sociopath lacks values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasp of non-instrumental goodness.
Psychopathy is a kind of perpetual infantilism.
Linguistic competence enhances cognitive competence.
There is nothing to thinking other than manipulating symbols (rejected position).
Anything thinkable with symbols is thinkable without them (alternative position, also problematic).
One must figure out what is meant by complex expressions; meaning cannot be directly determined by convention for complex expressions.
Without linguistic competence, a creature could not think discursively at the level of Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations.
Linguistic competence is constitutively, not merely causally, related to cognitive competence.
It is a conceptual necessity, not an idiosyncrasy of human psychology, that certain cogitations need linguistic vehicles.
There is subpersonal thought underlying conscious, pre-conscious, and repressed ideation.
Subpersonal cognitive operations mediate vision, language-comprehension, and musical ability.
Your mind figures out how to convert sensory disturbances into visual images, but not you (your self).
It would be viciously regressive to say the self carried out cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.
Perception is not mere sensation; perceptions are articulated sensations.
Articulations of perception correspond to conceptual knowledge.
Subpersonal, non-iconic ideation becomes hewed to sequences of expression-images.
Pleasant affects alert us to certain structural features in works of art.
Congenial phenomenology alerts us to positive properties like truthfulness and validity in expression-image series.
The nucleus of one's self is consciousness.
We don't grasp universals except by way of linguistic symbols (at the personal level).
Our minds can grasp universals non-linguistically at the subpersonal level.
Berkeley conflated images with concepts using the word "idea" for both.
Images are not concepts; universals are grasped through conception.
Empiricism cannot countenance non-image-mediated thought.
Concepts are not constituents of consciousness but are access-conscious.
Empiricism is inimical to the idea of invisible structure.
A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object.
Expressions like "the absolute is one" contain undefined terms and therefore say nothing until those terms are defined.
Russell, Tarski, and other logicians were wrong that there are meaningless bona fide sentences.
Alleged antinomies are either false or are sentence-schemata, not actual sentences.
Russell's Paradox does not demonstrate a counterexample to the Axiom of Comprehension.
The expression "the property of not being a member of itself" does not have a referent; it only appears to have a sense.
K₁ ("K is a member of itself") fails to encode a proposition because "itself" doesn't refer to anything.
The occurrence of "itself" in Russell's paradox lacks a sense.
The rules of English semantics are not at fault for apparent paradoxes.
When "self" functions anaphorically, it is eliminable.
Type Theory (TT) is self-defeating because it is given by a sentence that violates its own stricture.
There are two classes of antinomies: meaningless ones and false ones.
"This sentence is false" tokens are neither true nor false, not both true and false.
The semantic rules of English do not permit the construction of sentences that violate the Law of Non-Contradiction.
Natural languages are not defective in the way logicians have alleged.
What a sentence-token affirms depends on what its parts refer to (principle of compositionality).
Sentence-types are not individuated by the physical properties of their tokens.
Meaning cannot be use.
There are meaningful expressions that are never used literally and infinitely many that aren't used at all.
Once you know what an expression means, you won't acquire new knowledge about that meaning by acquiring additional knowledge of how that word is used.
To say anything, one must produce words intentionally; involuntary utterances are not speech.
In order for anything to mean anything, there must be semantic rules.
Duly rule-governed usage of an expression is governed by, and therefore doesn't constitute, its meaning.
Concepts are the meanings of predicates, not psychological entities.
To know that "number" is the word whose usage one is to study, one must already grasp the concept of number.
Semantic analysis (what linguists do) must not be confused with conceptual analysis (what philosophers do).
Words are not individuated strictly by the acoustical properties of their tokens.
Two sounds being tokens of the same word requires same meaning, sufficient acoustic similarity, and bona fide speech.
Wittgenstein's view that meanings don't exist has been refuted.
Platonic objects, if they exist, are not useless for explaining understanding.
Knowing a rule and knowing how to apply it are not separate achievements requiring infinite regress.
Rule-following is not a strictly psychological phenomenon.
The difference between someone who understands why F(13) = 169 and someone who believes it spuriously is not psychological.
Thinking is not a psychological process in the sense Wittgenstein supposed.
Knowledge of how to apply a rule is built into knowledge of that rule.
Chomsky's distinction between competence and performance resolves apparent problems about rule application.
Competence is ability; performance is the ability to deploy ability.
There is no gulf between knowing a principle and knowing how to apply it under given circumstances.
Given only a person's psychological condition, it is completely indeterminate what that person is thinking (Wittgenstein's false conclusion).
Working with different functions is not psychologically identical.
No accompaniments of rule-following are necessary or sufficient for that act of compliance.
When Wittgenstein refers to "accompaniments" of thought, he refers only to phenomenology, ignoring propositional attitudes.
Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
The deployment of a propositional attitude is not constitutive of consciousness.
Consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under his car's hood.
Mental imagery sometimes is thought-constitutive, contrary to Wittgenstein.
Thought-constitutive mental images are segments of ratiocinations that mostly do not consist of imagery.
Phenomenologically consecutive images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint.
Wittgenstein failed to distinguish access-consciousness from phenomenal consciousness.
Private language is not impossible; Wittgenstein's argument fails.
It isn't always other people who penalize those who misuse words.
Wittgenstein confuses language-misuse with language-shift.
Any given language is only as useful to its speakers as their memories of its semantic rules are good.
A manuscript of which there are many copies is not more of a manuscript than one of which there is only one (analogy for private language).
Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist.
Creatures in whom there are no occult processes are zombies, and zombies cannot be acculturated.
Groups of appropriately interrelated zombies do not collectively think (contra Brandom).
Empiricists cannot grant the existence of propositions.
If propositions don't exist, translation becomes inexplicable.
Quine's view that no sentence is a translation of any sentence is desperate and false.
One cannot learn a language by regarding speakers as thought-free bodies.
The Argument from Analogy for other minds is valid.
Wittgenstein's rejection of the Argument from Analogy is spurious.
We sometimes only need experience of one instance to make reliable generalizations.
Wittgenstein's contention that philosophical argumentation is misconceived was a post hoc attempt to legitimate his wanting arguments.
Quine and Wittgenstein, operating independently, reached the same radically counterintuitive conclusion about interpreting others.
The view that one must focus only on body movements when interpreting others is not empirically motivated but a consequence of strict empiricism.
Knowledge of one's propositional attitudes is access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.
Definitions are not analytic; they describe empirical facts about linguistic usage.
There are deep analytic truths that are primitive and cannot fail to be primitive.
Some analytic truths are absolutely primitive; others are absolutely non-primitive.
7 + 5 = 12 is not analytic in the sense that one knows it by analyzing constituent concepts.
Arithmetical truths are known through pure reason, not sense-perception.
Kant's view that mathematical truths are synthetic a priori is flawed.
Kant erroneously made mathematics a branch of psychology.
Kant's use of "transcendental" obfuscates his actual psychologistic view.
Geometrical propositions are non-empirical but not known through introspection.
Mental images are vehicles for geometrical thought but one doesn't know geometry by studying images.
Knowledge that one can or cannot imagine something is empirical and a posteriori.
Hume conflated knowledge of abstracta with introspective knowledge.
One cannot know the self through sense-perception or any inwardly-directed analogue thereof.
Hume's argument that there is no self fails because it assumes introspective knowledge is the only non-empirical knowledge.
Introspection is conceptual, not sensory or para-sensory, in nature.
Knowledge of one's conscious condition is empirical as a conceptualization of experience, like a scientific theory.
Having a mental image is not introspecting; introspecting involves noting that one is having such an image.
Animals must have concepts given they have sense-perceptions.
Animals' minds grasp abstracta even though the animals themselves do not.
Dogs and snakes are capable of conceptual ideation at the subpersonal level.
The Chomskyan unconscious is impersonal; the Freudian unconscious is personal.
There is no intrinsic difference between a propositional attitude that is repressed and one that isn't.
There are intrinsic differences between personal and subpersonal strata of mentation.
One must distinguish self from mind, and the part of mind with which one identifies from another unconscious part.
There are two very different kinds of unconsciousness: personal (Freudian) and impersonal (Chomskyan).
Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur given obvious facts.
Husserl failed to see the bearing of his non-empiricism on his attempts to scientize psychology.
One cannot drain introspections of all conceptual articulations; phenomenological bracketing is impossible.
Perception cannot be described except on the assumption that it is veridical.
Qua student of the mind, one cannot be a strict empiricist.
Science is not about sticking to the facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures.
Dennett and Churchland's eliminativism about the mental, if cogent, would establish the non-existence of the non-mental as well.
Paraperception is sub-personal truth-awareness embodied in personal object-awareness.
The delight one takes in listening to a Bach fugue embodies subpersonal awareness of truths about structural properties of sounds.
Subpersonal awarenesses are expressed at the personal level in the form of phenomenological episodes.
There is such a thing as subpersonal mentation.
Subpersonal knowledge is never transferred from one mental stratum to another.
Conscious knowledge of subpersonal processes is merely an analogue of those processes, not a duplicate.
The conscious conceit implanted by the psychoanalyst is a bona fide duplicate of its repressed counterpart.
Subpersonal knowledge described by Chomsky et al. is qualitatively very different from its conscious analogues.
Sub-personal processes are not strictly physiological; they embody intelligence and are not purely reflexive (contra Searle).
The English language is a collection of rules.
Semantic rules of the form "x refers to y" are highly complex.
People absorb and apply linguistic rules without the slightest difficulty.
Linguistic competence is naturally characterized as mastery of semantic rules.
The rules of linguistic competence are not access-conscious.
Linguistic rules are either access-unconscious in some deeper sense or they don't exist; the latter view is not viable.
There is no viable purely physiological characterization of linguistic competence.
If you have conscious, discursive knowledge of word meanings, that knowledge wouldn't operate quickly enough for real-time language comprehension.
Mentality and consciousness are not identical.
Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness.
When propositional attitudes are "conscious," it is in the sense that they are access-conscious.
There is no a priori reason why anything access-conscious must be so.
Any given consciousness must be distinct from its object.
Distinct objects are such that the existence of one is not logically dependent on the existence of the other.
There is no a priori reason why propositional attitudes must be access-conscious.
It is coherent to suppose that consciousness might have trouble accessing a given propositional attitude.
It often takes considerable intellectual resources to be consciously aware of what one believes.
Even if beliefs aren't repressed, one may lack the wherewithal to conceptualize them properly.
It's one thing to have cognitive wherewithal for first-order representations; quite another to correctly conceive of that wherewithal.
Without meta-cognitive wherewithal, one can't know what one's propositional attitudes are.
Searle's view (SV) that mentality is identical with consciousness is logically false.
Searle is a dispositionalist about non-consciousness-constitutive mental entities.
Dispositionalism doesn't model the data.
If beliefs were merely dispositions, knowledge-constitutive beliefs would be nothing more than arbitrary opinions.
Non-occurrent mental structures are functioning as mental entities between bouts of generating conscious states and behaviors.
Searle's view commits the quantifier-shift fallacy.
There are infinitely many sentences one understands and infinitely many derived semantic rules.
The a priori likelihood of two speakers' psychologies being perfectly aligned to their respective physiologies is small.
Medical science individuates brain-centers on the basis of their presumptive cognitive functions.
Brain-physiology is done in light of knowledge of psychophysical concomitances.
Mozart's and Beethoven's musical competencies differ physiologically much more than they do cognitively.
Cognitive processes are realized by physiological processes, but psychological relations between physiological events cannot be understood in physiological terms.
Hume grants that causal statements are sometimes true but holds they only describe regularity-instantiation.
Hume's analysis (HC) doesn't distinguish actual from epiphenomenal causality.
Day doesn't cause night, even though night regularly follows day.
We know intuitively what causes what before looking for regularities.
Constant conjunctions tip us off to continuities, to causal mechanisms.
It's the mechanism, the continuity, that is the sine qua non of causality.
To the extent an investigator's methodology is empiricist, he is blind to the invisible.
Empiricist philosophers of science deny that anything makes anything happen.
Hume's analysis assumes changes consist of events, but they don't.
The spatiotemporal world doesn't consist of discrete events.
The world has an analogue, not a digital structure.
The redistributions of mass-energy that constitute change do not have a digital structure.
Observation represents change as seamless, not as consisting of discrete parts.
One who witnesses continuity knows he is witnessing causation.
The world doesn't consist of truths; it consists of facts.
Truths hold in virtue of facts but aren't identical with facts.
Events are nominalizations of truths, not constituents of the external world.
Spatiotemporally coincident events with different modal properties would entail some region of space-time isn't self-identical.
Hume's analysis of causation involves a failure to distinguish facts from truths.
There can be no spatiotemporal changes without causal changes because spatiotemporal changes are causal changes.
Notions such as displacement and occupancy are to be understood in causal terms.
Hume assumes the concepts of precedence in time and adjacency in space can be understood in non-causal terms, but they cannot.
A "Hume world" without causation is impossible because any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.
If a ball's state at t isn't responsible for its state at t*, there are no grounds for saying they constitute one ball.
There is a transcendental argument for the existence of instances of causation.
Genidentical thought-episodes are the relata of bona fide instances of causation.
There is no such thing as a conceptually innocent observation-report.
If purged of theoretical commitments, observation-reports would be stilted and useless.
Goodman's puzzle shows that explanation isn't about finding regularities and subsuming events under them.
Certain regularities are broken and explanatorily useless; they are discontinuity-generators.
Good regularities destroy more discontinuities than they create.
Hyper-continuities make a regularity good, not vice versa.
We are interested in regularities only insofar as they are hyper-continuity-conducive.
There is change; change in the manner of change; change in the manner of the manner of change; and so on.
What we typically refer to as changelessness are conditions of high-order changelessness teeming with lower-order changes.
Data supports regularity-generating mechanisms; it doesn't directly support regularities.
Probability is not a statistical but an explanatory notion.
Wittgenstein's argument against other minds assumes probability is statistical, which is false.
The "axiom of diversity" is easily explained and shouldn't be an axiom.
Explanatory probability is a causal notion.
Empiricists deny anything makes anything happen, so they cannot distinguish statistical from explanatory probability.
The "problem of the priors" cannot be solved on statistical grounds; it has to be solved on grounds of causality and continuity.
Selves are not identical with the mental activity they mediate.
It isn't because two segments of a thought process belong to the same mind that they constitute one unbroken thought process; causation creates unity.
It is because thought-segments cohere that they belong to some one mind.
The self consists of awareness-mediating enduring structures underlying mental activity.
What unites a cryogenically frozen brain with its reactivated state is the persistence of a single structure that mediates ideation.
It is possible for all constituents of a given system to fall within its scope.
There are two ways a system can be organized: horizontally and vertically.
Nothing makes anything happen (NC) is Hume's legacy to the philosophy of science, but it is false.
The Deductive-Nomological (DN) analysis of explanation follows from the empiricist analysis of causation.
DN fails because there are infinitely many antecedents of any event that instantiate infinitely many universal generalizations.
Natural laws support counterfactuals, but advocates of DN cannot coherently say this.
To show that x is an instance of a regularity is to show it is one member of a whole class of events we can't explain.
Regularities are but shadows cast by underlying causal mechanisms.
Psychology explains by rationalizing; physicists do not, but both seek causal mechanisms.
Physical and psychological explanations share the property of seeking causal mechanisms.
Most psychological "explanations" fail DN's criteria, but this discredits DN, not those explanations.
A given event E₁ can cause E₂ even if, given E₁'s occurrence, there was less than 100% chance of E₂'s occurrence.
ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY CHAPTER 1 POSITION STATEMENT
Philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world.
We understand the world through categories (event, cause, thing, mind, perception, belief, knowledge, language, truth, value-judgment, law, justice, etc.).
These categories are seldom objects of thought, even though we cannot think without them.
We are adept at using categories but have difficulty making explicit the conditions that govern them.
Self-understanding is not the mind's primary function.
The idea of a mind that thinks about nothing other than itself is incoherent.
Any case of self-awareness is necessarily derivative of, and of lesser quality than, some more fundamental sort of understanding.
Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge—the analysis of analysis, the logic of logic, the science of science.
Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge.
The philosopher wants to know the laws governing the laws—what it would even make sense to claim to hold.
The philosopher is to the physicist what the physicist is to the engineer.
Pre-Fregean philosophers (with some exceptions) mistakenly thought they were studying the most general features of the actual world.
Frege showed that philosophers' interest in the actual is subordinate to their interest in the possible.
Analytic philosophers figure out what there could be by analyzing statements.
Statements that make sense describe possible realities; those that don't, don't.
Frege's key insight: logical form ≠ grammatical form.

When people have an obviously correct belief that seems to have an absurd consequence, they often accept the absurdity and develop ad hoc hypotheses rather than questioning whether the absurdity really follows.
Philosophical insight is acquired not by doing parascience or positing entities, but by analyzing meanings and clarifying statements.
"Nothing is a square circle" does not attribute a property to a non-entity; it states that the set of squares doesn't overlap with the set of circles.
The concept of "non-entities" or "subsistent entities" (Brentano, Meinong) is absurd—such philosophers were ontologizing when they should have been analyzing.
Hallucinations do not require the existence of non-existent objects; they have for their content an existence-claim that nothing satisfies.
Scientific puzzles involve acquiring new data; philosophical puzzles are purely conceptual and result from confusion, not ignorance.
Scientific breakthroughs have two components: (i) new raw data and (ii) new conceptual modeling of already-known data.
Philosophical puzzles are not solved by generating new raw data—they result from failure to draw the right inferences.
Wittgenstein was wrong to claim that all philosophical puzzles are linguistic in nature.
There are philosophical puzzles that have nothing to do with language.
Propositions are not sentences; propositions are the things meant by sentences.
Propositions exist independently of human beings; they are not human creations, whereas sentences are.
Propositions are properties; truth is instantiatedness.
The world was a certain way before we were around, so propositions (as ways the world is) exist independently of our beliefs.
Analytic philosophy (broadly construed) is philosophy done in the careful, clear-headed, systematic way that Frege approached problems.
The claim that one can know something only by being causally affected by it (e.g., Fodor's position regarding knowledge of mathematical truths) is absurd in the extreme.
The fact that 1+1=2 is non-spatiotemporal; nothing outside space-time can bear causal relations to anything.
The dispute over causal theories of knowledge is not linguistic—it concerns whether an agreed-upon meaning is true.
No philosophical assertions are empirical; observation cannot tell you whether one statement is inconsistent with another.
The question of whether law requires morality (legal positivism vs. anti-positivism) is to be resolved through logical, not empirical, analysis.
Logical positivism (LP) holds that meaningful statements are either tautologies or empirical.
LP is self-refuting: it is neither a tautology nor empirically verifiable, so by its own criterion it is meaningless.
There are non-empirical truths that have nothing to do with anyone's linguistic practices.
Strictly observational grounds cannot support theoretical statements like Newton's physics directly—only in conjunction with specific factual claims.
Wittgenstein's acknowledgment that the Tractatus is meaningless by its own standards is self-contradictory; to understand something is to see its meaning.
Empiricism is self-refuting: if true, there are no grounds for believing it; if there are grounds, it is false.
Russell's argument against naïve realism ("if true, is false; therefore false") rests on spurious reasoning—we do observe external objects, not merely effects upon ourselves.
The greenness, hardness, and coldness of physics are identical with those of daily observation; physics tells us what these properties are.
The concept of confirmation is incoherent unless non-empirical knowledge is granted (Goodman's grue argument).
Induction does not have a strictly observational basis; there must be non-observational grounds for preferring certain properties over others in inductive inference.
It is utterances, not sentences per se, that are tautologies—tautologousness depends on how the auditor learned the meanings of expressions.
One knows the meanings of expressions descriptively; two different descriptions can pick out the same thing.
All entailment is not formal entailment (contra Wittgenstein's Tractatus).
"Brown is a circle" entails "Brown is a two-dimensional figure," but this is not a formal entailment—it is a non-tautologous, non-empirical truth.
The concept of a logically perfect language is incoherent.
If a logically perfect language existed, it would be expressively inferior to natural languages.
For each analytic truth a logically perfect language could express, there would be infinitely many it could not express.
Knowing that a formal entailment is valid requires knowing that some informal entailment is valid; there are infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one.
There cannot be strictly observation-based knowledge that an object's length is given by an irrational number (Hempel's argument).
Modern physics depends on assumptions (that magnitudes can assume irrational values) for which there cannot be strictly observational grounds.
Strict empiricism is inconsistent with the fact that modern physics is a source of knowledge.
Euclid's axioms (1)–(5) are statement-forms, not statements proper, and some interpretations of them are false.
The parallel postulate is not true or false of anything—it is a statement-form.
Arithmetical truth cannot be formalized: any formal characterization of arithmetic is either inconsistent or incomplete.
The possible worlds analysis of counterfactuals (Lewis, Kment, Stalnaker) is completely preposterous.
We don't know anything about other universes; any knowledge of them would be parasitic on knowledge of counterfactual truths.
Counterfactuals are grammatical variants of ordinary causal or logical statements.
"Someone" is not in the same semantic category as "John" or "Ethel"—it does not refer to an individual.
"Someone smokes" does not attribute the property of smoking to a non-specific individual; it states that the property of being a smoker is instantiated.
There is no such thing as an "ambiguous person" or "non-specific entity"—to posit such things is to twist reality to conform to grammatical assumptions.
The word "someone" is not ambiguous; it has one meaning.
Analytic philosophers solve problems by clarifying statements, not by ontologizing (positing entities not previously believed to exist).
When analytic philosophers do ontologize, they posit only abstract, non-spatiotemporal entities—never spatiotemporal denizens like persons or tables.
Properties exist; their existence is validated by obviously true statements (e.g., "Bob and Sally are both intelligent").
Properties are not identical with spatiotemporal entities; you will never encounter intelligence per se in space-time.
The essence of the mental is intentionality (non-derivative representationality), as Brentano held.
Perception is description—seeing Larry involves seeing that various properties are instantiated.
Perceptions represent objects by encoding existence-claims that those objects satisfy.
The content of a perception is given by an existence-claim, not by a semantically simple symbol.
Hallucinations are representational not because they pick out non-existent objects, but because they encode false existence-claims.
Thoughts about non-existent things (e.g., an even prime greater than two) involve thinking false existence-claims.
Wittgenstein's view that philosophical problems arise only when sentences are misused is incorrect.
Wittgenstein's Tractatus holds that philosophical statements violate hidden syntactic rules; the Investigations holds they result from using words in non-standard ways—both positions are wrong.
One cannot learn about concepts by studying word usage unless one can already grasp the concept independently of the word.
Wittgenstein's thesis that "meaning is use" is incoherent.
If two expressions could only differ in meaning by being used differently, then any two sentences that have never been used would have the same meaning—which is absurd.
Conceptual role semantics (CRS)—the thesis that two sentences have the same meaning iff used the same way—is indefensible.
Someone who utters a sentence does so because she knows semantic rules assign a certain proposition to those words and she wishes to express that proposition.
Carnap's view that for a lecture to concern triangles is for the word "triangle" to occur in the lecture is false.
The very essence of logical positivism is the denial of meaning (propositions).
It is not up to us whether meanings (propositions) are correct, even though it is up to us what our symbols mean.
Logical truths are never sentences; they are always propositions.
Propositions are never conventionally true; linguistic conventions are known empirically, but what those conventions express is not itself empirical.
Logical positivists were unanimous in denying the existence of propositions and meanings generally.
Sentences like "the universe is a perfect unity" are not meaningless because they are non-empirical; they are meaningless because key terms are undefined—they are statement-forms, not statements.
Once undefined terms are defined, previously "meaningless" sentences become meaningful and true or false.
A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object; it is meaningless if it does not attribute any property to anything.
Any non-compound sentence either says of some individual that it has some property or says that two or more individuals are interrelated in a certain way.

**Position Statement: Kant & Hume on Induction, Causation, and the Methodology of Human Sciences**

This paper presents a systematic critique of Kant’s and Hume’s approaches to induction, causation, and the foundations of human sciences, while proposing a revised framework that reconciles their insights within a de-psychologized, logically grounded epistemology.

### **1. Critique of Kant’s Synthetic A Priori** - **Kant’s error lies in his narrow conception of analyticity.** He restricts analytic truths to trivial, self-evident propositions (e.g., “circles are round”), while labeling substantive but non-empirical truths (e.g., “7+5=12”) as *synthetic a priori*. - **This distinction collapses** when we recognize that many so-called synthetic a priori truths are actually *hard analytic*—truths grounded in conceptual structures but requiring non-trivial reasoning to uncover. - **Kant’s reliance on “intuition”** as a source of synthetic a priori knowledge is misguided. Intuition, for Kant, is a para-perceptual process that reveals how we *must* perceive the world, not how the world *is*. This leads to a psychologization of necessity and undermines the objective validity of a priori knowledge. - **Kant’s transcendental arguments can be salvaged** by reinterpreting them in logical rather than psychological terms. Where Kant speaks of *synthetic a priori* truths, we should speak of *hard analytic* truths—conceptually necessary but non-obvious propositions.

### **2. Critique of Hume’s Induction and Causation** - **Hume’s skepticism about induction and causation** rests on a *digital* conception of reality: events are discrete, point-like, and causally isolated. This view is both empirically and conceptually untenable. - **Reality is analogue, not digital.** Spatiotemporal events are continuous and causally interconnected. Descriptions of events as discrete are *models* of reality, not reality itself. - **Hume’s puzzle of induction** arises from conflating *propositional data* (e.g., “all observed swans are white”) with the *non-propositional, perceptual data* that actually grounds our inductive practices. The latter is continuous and causally structured, providing a logical (analogue-logical) basis for induction. - **Causation is inherent in continuity.** Temporal and spatial relations are themselves causal notions. There is no such thing as a non-causal description of a spatiotemporal event.

### **3. Proposed Synthesis: Analogue Logic and Hard Analyticity** - **We must distinguish between digital and analogue representations.** Language and propositions are digital; perception and reality are analogue. Logical relations exist in both, but analogue logic is more fundamental. - **Induction is an analogue-logically valid inference** from perceptual data. Counter-inductive hypotheses are not merely improbable but *analogue-logically invalid* because they imply discontinuities incompatible with the causal structure of reality. - **Explanation is not mere subsumption under regularities** (as Hume and Hempel thought), but the uncovering of *principled, causal connections* that are logically entailed by the structure of reality.

### **4. Implications for Human Sciences** - **Psychology and natural science are not methodologically divided.** Both seek principled explanations, not mere statistical regularities. The Dilthey–Hempel debate is a false dichotomy rooted in Humean misconceptions. - **Freud’s unconscious, for example,** is not an irrational postulate but a logical extension of the principle that psychological reality, like physical reality, is continuous and causally structured. - **Kuhn’s paradigm theory** overreacts to positivist shortcomings by retreating into relativism. A better approach recognizes that theory choice is guided by *analogue-logical consistency* with perceptual data, not mere convention or aesthetics.

### **5. Conclusion** The paper argues for a *de-psychologized Kantianism* and a *de-digitalized Humeanism*. By recognizing: - The existence of *hard analytic* truths, - The *analogue* and *causal* structure of reality, - The *logical* (not psychological) basis of induction and explanation,

we can construct a robust epistemology that preserves the insights of Kant and Hume while avoiding their psychologistic and skeptical pitfalls. This framework supports the rationality of both natural and human sciences, grounding them in a logically structured, causally continuous reality.

**Keywords:** Kant, Hume, synthetic a priori, analyticity, induction, causation, analogue logic, transcendental arguments, philosophy of science, epistemology.MISCELLANEOUS KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENTS

# 100 Positions from "How Is Rationalization Possible?"
## On Self-Deception and Its Possibility
People routinely deceive themselves, and it would be hard to exaggerate how often or how discrepantly from truth.
The view that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is itself a case of self-deception.
The view that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.
There are two distinct kinds of repression (repression₁ and repression₂).
There are correspondingly two kinds of self-deception, as a corollary of there being two kinds of repression.
## On Repression₁ (Epistemic Avoidance)
Repression₁ involves inaction—a deliberate, conscious intention not to follow up on suggestive leads.
Repression₁ involves suspecting but not knowing, and wanting to keep it that way.
Repression₁ involves not exercising due diligence in interpreting existing evidence or generating new evidence.
Repression₁ does not involve driving an already-formed belief into the unconscious.
Repression₁ involves abstaining from doing things that would generate evidence making acceptance of a belief de rigueur.
The customary conception of repression (CCR) is erroneous.
Suspicion is not knowledge, and there is nothing paradoxical about not wanting to pursue suspicions one suspects would lead to unwanted knowledge.
One can know what sort of thing something is without knowing which particular thing it is.
## On Repression₂ (Dissociation of Existing Beliefs)
Repression₂ involves already-formed beliefs.
The essence of repression₂ is dissociation.
To repress₂ an idea is to take away its "vote" in decision-making—to give it no weight.
Repression₂ involves blinding oneself to an existing belief one has already formed.
## On the Mechanisms Enabling Repression
The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind.
The mind is not a perfectly unified entity; it consists of parts that communicate imperfectly.
There are two very different ways of being aware of something: knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by description.
There are two very different senses in which mental content can be "conscious": as a constituent of consciousness, or as something one is conscious of.
The word "conscious" is used equivocally—sometimes meaning "constituent of consciousness," sometimes meaning "mental entity we are directly conscious of."
## On the Nature of Beliefs and Propositional Attitudes
All mental entities that aren't constituents of consciousness are, in one sense, unconscious.
Beliefs exist and are operative even when one is not conscious of them.
A belief can be psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness.
Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
One can, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of one of one's own propositional attitudes.
Emotions are distinct from their manifestations in consciousness.
Emotions are enduring psychological structures, not ephemeral events.
Beliefs, like emotions, are enduring structures distinguishable from the constituents of consciousness they may cause.
All propositional attitudes are enduring structures distinguishable from any constituents of consciousness for whose existence they're responsible.
Given two qualitatively distinct conscious events both expressing one propositional attitude, there isn't necessarily reason to recognize the attitude in both.
One can have very different attitudes towards a given one of one's own propositional attitudes without knowing it.
## On Judgment and Self-Knowledge
Having a propositional attitude is distinct from knowing that one has it.
Knowing one feels a certain way involves making a judgment about one's mental state.
Propositional attitudes never appear in consciousness in propria persona, except indirectly as rocks and trees do.
What is in consciousness is at most a representative or derivative of a propositional attitude.
One must "synthesize" indications of one's attitudes; one must make a judgment that they express an enduring attitude.
These synthesis-judgments are often quite wrong.
We sometimes like those toward whom we have constant surges of rage; we sometimes dislike those who make us feel good.
## On Limitations of Agency Over Mental Processes
One's agency only goes so far; much within one's mind falls outside its scope.
Judgment-producing processes lie beyond the reach of what one can choose to occur.
It is not within one's power to completely suspend judgment-producing processes.
One can no more choose to stop making judgments than choose to stop digesting food.
One can choose courses of action that redirect automatically-occurring mental activity that yields judgments.
Unless one damages one's brain, the stream of judgment-making activity will eventually yield the judgments one doesn't want.
## On Anxiety and Repression₁
The anxiety felt when repression₁ breaks down isn't from unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.
It results from one's thought-processes following up on clues despite attempts to stymie them.
Every case of repression₁ involves intrapsychic conflict, but not between unconscious knowledge and conscious ignorance.
The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know it.
## On Conditions for Repression₂
For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's psyche.
It isn't enough for something to be painful for it to be repressed₂.
People typically choose to suppress painful memories, but suppression isn't repression₂.
One represses₂ knowledge that would severely disrupt one's life-structure if consciously admitted.
## On the Value and Dangers of Repression₂
Repression₂ isn't always bad; in many contexts, it's optimal.
A person who never repressed₂ anything would quickly go mad.
Repressions₂ are necessary.
Repressions₂ outlive their usefulness—circumstances change but the repression persists.
Repression₂ isn't a one-off affair; it is an ongoing process.
Each instance of repression₂ creates holes in one's knowledge that must be explained away.
These explanations cannot be genuine and each incentivizes more bogus, anomaly-creating explanations.
The need to plug these holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value illegitimate reasoning methods.
The result of sustained repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.
## On Factors Conducive to Repression₂
One can know something without that thing being obvious to one.
It's harder to repress₂ knowledge of the obvious than of the non-obvious.
Inference-based knowledge is easier to repress₂ than sense-based knowledge.
People can repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths, but this requires telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.
Complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates.
In most cases of repression₂, there must be "plausible deniability."
The things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than pure sense-perception.
If a belief concerns something personal, one's standard of proof tends to be ridiculously high.
## On Freud's Principal Claims
Nobody is perfectly transparent to himself; nobody is conscious of everything in his mind.
Some mental contents are readily made conscious (pre-conscious); others are kept unconscious because distressing.
Repressed entities weren't destroyed; the subject merely blinded himself to them.
Desires arising from repressed material are necessarily intense and the subject experiences intolerable frustration until discharged.
Such desires cannot be discharged unless they employ subterfuge, since conscious intention to gratify them is impossible.
Subterfuges are of two types: disguise as an acceptable desire, or expression as a symptom.
## On Opposition to Freud
Arguments against Freud's contentions are pitifully weak and involve regressions to crude, demonstrably false positions.
The positions "we're computers," "there is no consciousness," "there are no minds," "the mind is completely transparent to itself" are all untenable.
Eliminativism about propositional attitudes ("folk psychology") is false.
Willful denials of the obvious are touted as "scientific" and "rigorous" without warrant.
While it's good not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not good not to impute them to people.
The projector itself cannot be a projection—one cannot eliminate the mental by treating it as projection.
## On the Mechanism of Repression₂ (Detailed)
Beliefs are inert except to the extent one draws consequences from them and allows them to engage other beliefs.
Some inferences are made involuntarily, but one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one's mind makes.
One can so structure one's life that a belief, though still conscious, is isolated—prevented from engaging other beliefs.
By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have more than abstract, formal understanding of it.
Most data-synthesis occurs below the threshold of consciousness.
Decisions about what goes on in one's mind are of limited scope—they don't directly affect deeper strata.
One cannot "uninstall" a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness.
The conscious representative of a repressed₂ belief becomes an innocuous shell, but the belief still lives on.
Since one no longer acknowledges the repressed belief's existence, it must insinuate itself into intentions or be expressed as symptoms.
## On Both Forms of Repression
Both repression₁ and repression₂ involve conflict between conscious and unconscious forces within oneself.
Both forms of repression involve constructing and operationalizing a narrative alternative to reality.
Both forms of repression involve rationalization.
Without rationalization, it is hard if not impossible to repress an idea and keep it repressed.
Rationalization-construction is more heavily involved in keeping ideas repressed than in initially repressing them.
## On Psychology as a Discipline
The science of psychology has itself become a means by which people rationalize attempts to repress obvious psychodynamic truths.
Brain-science, to the extent it's relevant to psychology, is parasitic on psychological knowledge.
The denial of emotions is itself a thoroughly emotional position, and the denial of repression is itself an instance of repression.MORE KUCZYNSKI MISCELLANEOUS POSITION STATEMENTS

### On Self-Deception and Its Possibility
People routinely deceive themselves, and it would be hard to exaggerate how often or how discrepantly with the truth.
The view that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is itself a case of self-deception.
There are two distinct kinds of repression, which correspond to two kinds of self-deception.
Repression₁ involves deliberate, conscious intention not to follow up on suggestive leads—one suspects but doesn't know, and wants to keep it that way.
Repression₁ doesn't involve driving an already-formed belief into the unconscious; it involves abstaining from doing things that would generate evidence making acceptance of that belief de rigueur.
Repression₂ involves already-formed beliefs and its essence is dissociation.
To repress₂ an idea is to take away its "vote"—to decide to give it no weight in one's decision-making.
Both forms of repression involve conflict between forces within oneself of which one is aware and forces of which one is unaware.
Both forms of repression involve constructing and operationalizing a narrative alternative to the one describing reality as it really is.
Both forms of repression involve rationalization; without rationalization, it is hard or impossible to repress an idea or keep it repressed.
### On the Structure of Mind
The mind is not a perfectly unified entity; it consists of various parts that communicate with each other only very imperfectly.
There are two very different ways one can be aware of a given thing: knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by description.
There are two very different senses in which mental content can be "conscious": as a constituent of consciousness, or as a mental entity of which one is conscious.
Sense-perceptions, itches, tickles, and other sensations are constituents of consciousness.
Your belief that 1+1=2 is not a constituent of consciousness; it is "conscious" only in the sense that you are, or can readily become, conscious of it.
The word "conscious" is used equivocally: sometimes meaning "mental entity that is a constituent of consciousness" and sometimes meaning "mental entity that we are directly conscious of."
All mental entities that aren't constituents of consciousness are, in a sense, unconscious.
A belief exists and is operative even when one is not conscious of it.
Your knowledge that 1+1=2 informs how you deal with the world even when you aren't consciously thinking it.
Given anything that isn't itself a constituent of consciousness, one can fail to recognize it for what it is.
### On Propositional Attitudes
Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
One could, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of one of one's own propositional attitudes.
Emotions are distinct from their manifestations in consciousness.
Love, hatred, and other emotions are enduring psychological structures, not ephemeral events.
Emotions give rise to ephemeral conscious events but are not themselves conscious events.
Emotions are "conscious" only in the Pickwickian sense that one is conscious of them.
Beliefs, like emotions, are enduring structures to be distinguished from the constituents of consciousness to which they may give rise.
All propositional attitudes are enduring structures to be distinguished from any constituents of consciousness for whose existence they're responsible.
A given emotion can give rise to conscious events of qualitatively different kinds.
Given two qualitatively distinct conscious events both expressing one propositional attitude, there's no necessity that one recognize that attitude in both events.
### On Self-Knowledge and Its Limits
One can have very different attitudes towards a given one of one's own propositional attitudes without knowing it.
One can view a given propositional attitude of one's own as both despicable and laudatory, as deserving cultivation and annihilation.
Self-deception is not mere ignorance of what one is feeling.
Self-deception presupposes that, at some level, one has knowledge of the thing of which one lacks conscious knowledge.
One must distinguish having a propositional attitude from knowing that one has it.
Knowing that one feels a certain way involves making a judgment about one's mental state.
Propositional attitudes never make an appearance in consciousness in propria persona.
What is in consciousness is at most a representative or derivative of a propositional attitude.
The judgments we make about what our mental states express are often quite wrong.
We sometimes like the person towards whom we have constant surges of rage, and dislike the person who repeatedly makes us feel good.
### On Manipulation and Self-Understanding
A manipulator can generate feelings that, when not the result of chicanery, tend to express genuine affection, thereby disarming his target.
One can know "in one's bones" that something is wrong about a situation without being able to articulate what it is.
Most people haven't developed the ability to articulate their gut feelings in a form likely to receive credence.
Given that one's views about others are based on glib, emotionally-driven narratives, one will fail to recognize manipulation.
### On Evidence and Suspicion
It's one thing to suspect that something is the case; it's quite another to know it.
Repression₁ involves choosing not to exercise due diligence when one suspects that doing so would generate unwanted knowledge.
The conventional conception of repression (that one knowingly drives a conscious idea into the unconscious and keeps it out) is erroneous.
Suspicion isn't knowledge; there's nothing paradoxical about not wanting to pursue suspicions one suspects would lead to unwanted knowledge.
One can know what sort of thing something is without knowing which thing it is.
### On the Limits of Agency
One's agency only goes so far; there is much within one's mind that falls outside its scope.
The judgment-producing processes in one's mind lie beyond the reach of what one can choose to occur.
It is not within one's power to completely suspend judgment-producing processes.
One cannot choose to stop making judgments any more than one can choose to stop digesting food.
One can choose courses of action that redirect the judgment-making faculty or deplete its energy.
Unless one damages one's brain, the stream of mental activity will eventually yield the very judgments one doesn't want.
### On Anxiety and Repression
The anxiety felt when forces of repression₁ break down isn't the result of unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.
Such anxiety results from one's thought-processes, despite attempts to stymie them, following up on clues one believed would lead to unwanted beliefs.
### On Repression₂ and Intrapsychic Conflict
For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's own psyche, not merely a source of pain.
One often fails to repress₂ one's most painful memories; Holocaust survivors remember what they've been through.
Suppression (choosing not to think about something) isn't repression₂.
One represses₂ knowledge that cannot be reconciled with one's life as currently structured.
Repression₂ isn't always bad; in many contexts, it's optimal.
A person who never repressed₂ anything would quickly go mad.
Repressions₂ tend to outlive their usefulness.
Repression₂ isn't a one-off affair; it is an ongoing process.
Whenever one encounters information confirming a repressed₂ belief, one must either repress₂ that knowledge or convince oneself of some spurious interpretation.
Each instance of repression₂ creates a hole in one's body of knowledge that must be explained away.
The need to plug explanatory holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value reasoning methods whose legitimacy spurious explanations falsely assume.
The result of ongoing repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.
### On What Gets Repressed
It's harder to repress₂ knowledge of the obvious than of the non-obvious.
One cannot repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths without telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.
Since complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates, repression₂ tends to target knowledge of what is not totally obvious.
In most cases of repression₂, there must be "plausible deniability."
Things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than strict sense-based knowledge.
If a belief concerns something personal, one's standard of proof tends to be ridiculously high.
### On Evolution and Self-Deception
People have always known that we evolved from other life forms, given the anatomical, behavioral, and psychological similarities between humans and other mammals.
The theory of evolution is resisted because it implies we're orangutans whose lives have no meaning.
Religious claims about divine creation don't explain why God made us look so much like apes or stocked our minds with ignominious urges.
### On Freud's Psychology
Freud's theories are theoretically extraordinarily conservative.
Freud was simply making explicit the principles we ordinarily use when making intuitive judgments about other people.
People dismiss Freud's theories, despite their staggering explanatory power, because they don't want to be told they lie to themselves.
Nobody is perfectly transparent to himself; nobody is conscious of everything in his mind.
One can readily become conscious of some previously unconscious mental constituents without resistance; these are "preconscious."
When one represses an entity, one doesn't destroy it; one merely blinds oneself to it.
A repressed desire cannot be discharged unless it employs a subterfuge.
Repressed desires can disguise themselves as desires the subject consciously wishes to act on.
Repressed desires can be expressed as symptoms.
### Against Eliminativism and Reductionism
Arguments against Freudian psychology are pitifully weak and involve regressions to crude, demonstrably false positions.
The views that "we're computers," "there is no consciousness," "there are no minds," and "the mind is completely transparent to itself" are willful denials of the obvious.
While it's a good idea not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not a good idea not to impute them to people.
The projector itself cannot be a projection; the mind cannot be eliminated from the scientific picture.
### On the Mechanism of Repression₂
One can partly de-operationalize beliefs one doesn't want by choosing not to delineate their consequences.
One can isolate a belief—prevent it from engaging bodies of belief it would otherwise engage and from begetting beliefs it would otherwise beget.
By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
One can choose to look for reasons to have beliefs opposed to those one wishes one didn't have, like a lawyer building a case for a client known to be guilty.
Even though one can't directly choose one's beliefs, one can choose to do things that make it harder to attend to a given belief than to withdraw attention from it.
### On Sub-Personal Processing
Most data-synthesis occurs below the threshold of consciousness.
The sub-personal gathering and processing of information is more fundamental than personal gathering and processing; minds are more basic than selves.
One's decisions about what goes on in one's mind are of limited scope, affecting how conscious strata communicate with other strata but not directly affecting deeper strata.
### On Psychology as a Discipline
Contemporary theoretical psychology's denial of emotions and repression is itself thoroughly emotional and an instance of repression—a rationalization serving to keep unwanted self-knowledge at bay.
## 100 Additional Philosophical Positions from "How Is Rationalization Possible?"
### On the Coherence of Self-Deception
The claim that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.
The apparent paradox of repression (that one must be conscious of what one represses) dissolves once one distinguishes repression₁ from repression₂.
The natures of both conscious and unconscious forces involved in repression₁ differ from those involved in repression₂.
Rationalization-construction is more heavily involved in keeping ideas repressed than in initially repressing them.
The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind: its disunity, the distinction between acquaintance and description, and the ambiguity of "conscious."
### On Mental Architecture
The right hand of the mind doesn't always know what the left is doing.
One can unwittingly have two divergent attitudes towards a single propositional attitude of one's own.
Given only that two conscious events are derivatives of some propositional attitude, it doesn't follow that any one part of one's mind has the information needed to recognize that attitude in both.
Were one's belief that 1+1=2 inoperative whenever not blazing a trail across consciousness, one's way of dealing with the world would bear little resemblance to one's actual way.
Supposing knowledge is identical with some physiological structure, that structure is psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness—not just as a heap of molecules.
### On Recognition and Concepts
One can have thoughts about Charlemagne and thus have a concept of him, yet fail to recognize him if one met him.
So long as one didn't figure out who Charlemagne was upon meeting him, one would unwittingly have two distinct concepts of him.
One can discover that the gnawing feeling of unpleasantness experienced when somebody mentions Smith is one's detestation of Smith.
One can be acquainted with a given one of one's own mental contents while also having descriptive knowledge of it.
One can discover that one actually has some attitude towards a mental entity that one did not previously know oneself to have.
### On Conscious Experience and Judgment
What one is directly given in consciousness are various indications that one has a particular emotion, not the emotion per se.
Even when indications of an emotion are strong enough to leave no room for reasonable doubt, one still must "synthesize" them by making a judgment.
In most cases, the judgment that synthesizes emotional indications is made so automatically that one is unaware any judgment has been made.
When a propositional attitude is emotionally sterile—concerning number-theory or epistemology—we have no trouble making the needed judgments about it.
Evidences of a propositional attitude may be dispersed over time and occur in multifarious contexts.
### On the Conventional Conception of Repression
Part (b) of the conventional conception of repression—that repressed content constantly struggles to break into consciousness—is paradoxical as stated.
The paradox arises because keeping content out of consciousness would seem to require knowing what that content is.
The conventional conception incorrectly describes repression as an operation performed on existing beliefs rather than a failure to form beliefs.
Repression₁ involves choosing not to learn something that, if learned and therefore known, one would wish one had never learned—but only after it was too late.
Every case of repression₁ does involve intrapsychic conflict, as the conventional conception says.
Contrary to the conventional conception, the conflict in repression₁ is not between unconscious knowledge of truth T and conscious ignorance of T.
The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know the truth.
### On Voluntary Control of Mental Processes
One can choose activities that flood the judgment-making faculty with information concerning judgments one wants to avoid making.
One can choose to do things that deplete the judgment-making faculty of energy it needs to function (e.g., intense exercise for hours).
One can choose to paralyze the physiological underpinnings of judgments (e.g., by getting drunk) or permanently damage them (e.g., by lobotomy).
One cannot directly choose what to believe; one can only choose what to believe in the way one can choose to gain weight.
Within limits, one can choose which beliefs to make operational and which to make non-operational.
One can choose to do things that make a given belief impotent and irrelevant.
One can choose an occupation in which a lack of some ability is irrelevant, thereby making one's knowledge of that lack irrelevant.
### On Standards of Evidence
What it would take to convince you that somebody you're not married to is cheating on his wife is minuscule compared to what it would take to convince you that your husband is cheating.
Because evolution implies we're meaningless orangutans, we won't judge it worthy of acceptance until it's met absurdly high standards of evidence.
Denying that orangutans are our biological kin is like denying that the person with grape jelly and crumbs around his mouth ate your jelly-doughnut.
### On Freud and His Critics
If you read Freud and then study a single person's behavior for around 10 minutes, it becomes clear his theories are theoretically conservative.
People don't want to part with rationalizations; they'd rather be a king in their dreams than a janitor in reality.
The opposition to Freud's claims involves regressions to crude positions: "We're computers" (Fodor), "There is no consciousness" (Dennett), "There are no minds" (Quine).
Searle's view that the mind is completely transparent to itself is a willful denial of the obvious.
The Churchlands' view that nobody believes, doubts, or hopes for anything—that propositional attitude terms belong to "folk-psychology"—is demonstrably false.
The Dretske-Fodor view that there is no difference between a concept of a person and a photograph of that person is risible.
These flights into inanity are touted as "scientific" and "rigorous" under the pretense of completing science's victory over animism.
While it's good not to impute minds to stones, the projector—the mind itself—cannot be a projection.
### On the Mechanism of Repression₂ (Detailed)
For one's knowledge of an ugly truth to be repressed₂, that knowledge, when taken with other accepted propositions, entails a more generic proposition.
The more generic proposition can be kept in consciousness without having to overhaul one's entire life.
The generic proposition is sufficiently vague that knowledge of it won't make one retch at the sight of the problematic object.
One can realize one wishes one hadn't discovered an ugly truth while also realizing that mere suppression won't suffice.
One can resolve that, when confronted with data that led to the ugly belief, one will model it in a way consistent with the generic belief but not with the specific ugly truth.
### On Beliefs and Inference
Beliefs are inert except to the extent that one draws consequences from them and that they are allowed to beget or engage other beliefs.
The making of inferences at least sometimes involves deliberate, conscious effort.
Some inferences are made involuntarily; insights often just occur to one based on rational consideration of evidence.
Even though many inferences are made involuntarily, one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one's mind makes.
One can so structure one's life that it is very unlikely one will consciously make inferences from a belief that one would otherwise make.
One can so structure one's life that a belief, though still conscious, is isolated—prevented from engaging bodies of belief and from begetting beliefs it otherwise would.
Such an isolated belief is conscious in some formal sense but has become inert at the level of consciousness, like knowledge of some random, uninteresting fact.
### On Abstract vs. Concrete Understanding
By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have anything more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
One can know that people are being tortured without knowing what that proposition amounts to as well as someone who witnessed torture.
Even if technically no less aware of a truth than someone with first-hand knowledge, one's awareness can mean very little compared to theirs.
First-hand knowledge transforms abstract awareness into something that means a great deal.
### On Inference to the Best Explanation
Knowledge of complex interpersonal truths is not derived from some one sense-perception; such truths can't be known that directly.
Such knowledge embodies inference to the best explanation.
Unless knowledge can be acquired through inferences to the best explanation, what we actually know is only an infinitesimally small part of what we think we know.
Given a body of data, it is more likely than not that there is more than one reasonable or semi-reasonable way to model it.
An alternative model of data need not be optimal; it need only be far from obviously false to serve repression₂.
### On the Process of Isolation
By deciding not to draw inferences from an ugly belief, one becomes more likely to take aberrant phenomena on a case-by-case basis.
Bits of knowledge that would otherwise congregate will remain isolated from one another when one resolves not to synthesize them.
As a result of isolation, one's appreciation of what an ugly truth entails will remain superficial.
One will be slow to recognize the consequences of an ugly truth for one's own welfare.
By isolating a belief, one ensures that energy and thought that would deepen understanding of its consequences are diverted to a fool's errand.
The response of modeling data in terms of a preferred alternative soon becomes automatic, like an actor's rehearsed lines.
This automatic response-mechanism further isolates the knowledge one wishes to suppress.
### On the Limits of Repression
One cannot uninstall a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness, just as one typically cannot uninstall a computer program by dragging the desktop icon to the garbage.
Beliefs are enduring structures; they do a lot of work even when not consciously deployed.
If one really stopped knowing that 1+1=2, one's way of dealing with the world would suddenly change radically, pervading practically every field of endeavor.
A belief isn't like a mood or other will-o'-the-wisps that populate consciousness.
Like any enduring structure constitutive of one's metabolism, one has at most partial control over a belief's fortunes.
The conscious representative of a repressed₂ belief becomes an innocuous shell—it has been repressed, but it still lives on.
A repressed₂ belief "presses for discharge" (Freud's term).
### On Symptoms and Displacement
Since one no longer acknowledges a repressed₂ belief's existence, it cannot be discharged through intentional behavior.
A repressed₂ belief must insinuate itself into one's intentions without one's knowing it.
Displacement occurs when repressed rage at one person is expressed as meanness toward another (e.g., rage at father displaced onto students).
A repressed₂ belief can be expressed as a symptom—e.g., crippling anxiety when encountering situations reminiscent of what was repressed.
### On Keeping Repression Stable
To keep something repressed₂, one must be able to identify it—but if one can identify it, one is conscious of it and it's not repressed.
The resolution of this paradox involves retaining knowledge of a generic proposition while repressing the specific ugly truth.
By accepting a generic version of an ugly truth, one's conscious disposition isn't completely antagonistic to the rational side urging acceptance of the specific truth.
Accepting the generic version means one isn't locked into a draining struggle with the forces of rationality and truthfulness within oneself.
At the same time, accepting the generic version neutralizes the message those forces are trying to convey.
This strategy spares one painful realizations and the labor-intensive changes they demand.
### On the Psychology Profession
The science of psychology has itself become little more than a means by which people rationalize attempts to repress knowledge of obvious psychodynamic facts.
Many claim the unconscious is an artifact of dated psychoanalytic theories superseded by "rigorous" physiological studies.
The thoroughly hypocritical and self-deceptive character of such pronouncements is evident when examining the judgments and conduct of these naysayers.
Not a single judgment these naysayers make about others concerns physiological underpinnings; they concern psychology.
PET-scan findings would be of no psychological interest unless correlated with independently known psychological facts.
If mental activity were discovered to be mediated by the gall-bladder, PET-scans would immediately cease to be of psychological interest.
Brain-science, to the extent it's relevant to psychology, is parasitic on psychological knowledge.
Most opponents of psychodynamic psychology provide no arguments other than empty slogans that "science" studies brains, not intangibles like emotions.
### On the Epistemological Priority of the Mental
Whatever we know about the external world—about brains, neurons—we know through perceptions and thoughts, i.e., through alleged "intangibles."
While brains may be ontologically more basic than thoughts, thoughts and perceptions are epistemologically more basic than brains.
"Brain" is a theoretical term; characterizing something as a brain ascribes functions one cannot know it discharges without theory-soaked extrapolation.
"Brain" is deeply entrenched in well-confirmed theory, hence the illusion that it is non-theoretical.
Psychological "intangibles" are epistemologically much more tangible than "tangible" things like brains.
The existence of psychological intangibles is infinitely less dubitable than that of brains.
### On Eliminativism as Emotional
The denial of emotions is itself a thoroughly emotional position.
The denial of repression is itself an instance of repression.
Those who deny emotions and repression claim to be "scientific," but such dishonesty and obtuseness doesn't deserve that characterization.
Hyper-intelligent people are quite as prone to not seeing themselves for who they are as their less gifted brethren.
Given that intelligence doesn't protect against self-ignorance, it is scientifically de rigueur to suppose another factor is operative.
That other factor is obvious: people don't want to see themselves for who they are, so they don't.
### On Sartre's Argument
Sartre held there is no unconscious mental activity and a fortiori no repression.
Sartre's position was that the mind is completely and utterly transparent to itself, immediate and complete access to all contents being essential to mentality.
Unlike other deniers of the unconscious, Sartre actually argued for his position.
Sartre's argument is initially persuasive: one must know what one is trying to keep out of consciousness to succeed, but that knowledge makes one conscious of it.
Given Sartre's argument, either he is right and his reasoning cogent, or he is wrong and the fallacy must be pinpointed.
The specific forms self-deception and repression can take may not be the forms they actually take.
There are elements of truth in the models presented for repression₁ and repression₂.
It is a philosophical task of the utmost urgency to make clear what is wrong with Sartre's powerful argument.
It is equally urgent to make clear what exactly self-deception and repression involve.
