POSITION STATEMENT WITH QUOTATIONS FOR CHAPTER 1 OF ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY BY KUCZYNSKI
# ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY CHAPTER 1: POSITION STATEMENT WITH SUPPORTING QUOTATIONS
**1. Philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world.**

> "Philosophy studies these categories. It delineates their structures. This is its sole function. Thus, philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world."
**2. We understand the world through categories (event, cause, thing, mind, perception, belief, knowledge, language, truth, value-judgment, law, justice, etc.).**
> "We understand the world in terms of certain categories (e.g., person, statement, fact, impossibility, existence)."
**3. These categories are seldom objects of thought, even though we cannot think without them.**
> "Whatever we know, we know it through these categories (and others like them—the list is not complete). But even though we cannot think without them, they are seldom the objects of thought."
**4. We are adept at using categories but have difficulty making explicit the conditions that govern them.**
> "The result is that, although we're adept at using them, we know little about them."
**5. Self-understanding is not the mind's primary function.**
> "In general, it's hard to identify the principles that guide our thoughts. Self-understanding isn't the mind's primary function."
**6. The idea of a mind that thinks about nothing other than itself is incoherent.**
> "Nor could it be. The idea of a mind that thinks about nothing other than itself is an incoherent one."
**7. Any case of self-awareness is necessarily derivative of, and of lesser quality than, some more fundamental sort of understanding.**
> "Thus, any case of self-awareness, and therefore of self-understanding, is necessarily derivative of, and for that reason of lesser quality than, some other more fundamental sort of understanding."
**8. Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge—the analysis of analysis, the logic of logic, the science of science.**
> "Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge. It is the analysis of analysis, the logic of logic, the science of science."
**9. Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge.**
> "Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge."
**10. The philosopher wants to know the laws governing the laws—what it would even make sense to claim to hold.**

> "The philosopher is interested in the laws governing the laws. He doesn't want to know what in fact holds. He wants to know what it would even make sense to claim to hold. He wants to know the laws that the laws can't break."
**11. The philosopher is to the physicist what the physicist is to the engineer.**
> "The philosopher is to the physicist what the physicist is to the engineer and, therefore, what the engineer is to the stranded motorist."
**12. Pre-Fregean philosophers (with some exceptions) mistakenly thought they were studying the most general features of the actual world.**
> "With some exceptions, pre-Fregean philosophers thought they were studying the most general features of the actual world."
**13. Frege showed that philosophers' interest in the actual is subordinate to their interest in the possible.**
> "Frege showed that this is wrong... But with philosophers, it's the other way around. Any interest they have in the actual is subordinate to their interest in the possible."
**14. Analytic philosophers figure out what there could be by analyzing statements.**
> "Unlike non-analytic philosophers, analytic philosophers figure out what there could be by analyzing statements."
**15. Statements that make sense describe possible realities; those that don't, don't.**

> "Statements that make sense are those that can be true, and statements that don't are those that can't. Therefore, statements that make sense describe possible realities and those that don't don't."
**16. Frege's key insight: logical form ≠ grammatical form.**
> "2.0 Frege's key insight: Logical form ≠ grammatical form"

**17. When people have an obviously correct belief that seems to have an absurd consequence, they often accept the absurdity and develop ad hoc hypotheses rather than questioning whether the absurdity really follows.**

> "(FL) When people have an obviously correct belief that seems to have an absurd consequence, they should ask themselves whether that absurdity really is a consequence of that belief. But they frequently don't. Instead they accept the absurdity and, in order to make this mistake of theirs work, they develop ad hoc hypotheses as to the nature of reality that undermine the integrity of their own belief system."
**18. Philosophical insight is acquired not by doing parascience or positing entities, but by analyzing meanings and clarifying statements.**
> "What this shows is that, in at least some cases, philosophical insight is acquired, not by doing parascience, but by analyzing meanings—not by positing entities, but by clarifying statements."
**19. "Nothing is a square circle" does not attribute a property to a non-entity; it states that the set of squares doesn't overlap with the set of circles.**

> "Since (i) and (ii) are just different ways of saying what SC says, the latter doesn't make the absurd statement that some non-entity is a circle, and it instead makes the innocuous statement that the set of squares doesn't overlap with the set of circles."
**20. The concept of "non-entities" or "subsistent entities" (Brentano, Meinong) is absurd—such philosophers were ontologizing when they should have been analyzing.**
> "This entire approach is misguided. Brentano and Meinong were ontologizing when they should have been analyzing."
**21. Hallucinations do not require the existence of non-existent objects; they have for their content an existence-claim that nothing satisfies.**

> "When we describe a thought or perception as having a 'non-existent object,' what we mean, so far as what we mean is coherent, is that it has for its content an existence-claim that nothing satisfies."
**22. Scientific puzzles involve acquiring new data; philosophical puzzles are purely conceptual and result from confusion, not ignorance.**

> "The puzzles that science deals with typically involve a failure to know all the facts... Unlike scientific puzzles, philosophical puzzles are not solved by generating new raw data. Philosophical puzzles are purely conceptual in nature and have no strictly factual component."
**23. Scientific breakthroughs have two components: (i) new raw data and (ii) new conceptual modeling of already-known data.**

> "In general, scientific breakthroughs have two components: (i) a strictly fact-based component (new raw data is acquired), and (ii) a purely conceptual component (already known data is modeled in a new and better way)."
**24. Philosophical puzzles are not solved by generating new raw data—they result from failure to draw the right inferences.**
> "Philosophical puzzles result, not from a failure to know the facts, but from a failure to draw the right inferences. They result, not from ignorance, but from confusion."
**25. Wittgenstein was wrong to claim that all philosophical puzzles are linguistic in nature.**

> "But this position is incorrect. There are many philosophical puzzles that don't have anything to do with language, and the solutions to these puzzles cannot be modeled on Frege's solutions to the puzzles discussed a moment ago."
**26. There are philosophical puzzles that have nothing to do with language.**
> "There are many philosophical puzzles that don't have anything to do with language."
**27. Propositions are not sentences; propositions are the things meant by sentences.**

> "Propositions are the things meant by sentences. 'Snow is white,' 'schnee is weiss,' and 'la neige est blanche' all mean the same thing. There is some one proposition that is the meaning of each of them."
**28. Propositions exist independently of human beings; they are not human creations, whereas sentences are.**

> "It's widely thought that propositions are human creations. This is false... it follows from this that propositions are not human creations. Sentences, on the other hand, are human creations. They wouldn't be around if it weren't for us."
**29. Propositions are properties; truth is instantiatedness.**
> "Propositions must be identified with properties and a proposition's being true must be identified with its being instantiated. Propositions are properties and truth is instantiatedness."
**30. The world was a certain way before we were around, so propositions (as ways the world is) exist independently of our beliefs.**

> "The world was a certain way before we were around; it will be a certain way after we're gone; and the way it is while we're around is up to us only to a limited extent. It follows that, independently of our having any beliefs or, indeed, our doing or thinking anything, certain propositions are true."
**31. Analytic philosophy (broadly construed) is philosophy done in the careful, clear-headed, systematic way that Frege approached problems.**
> "The word 'analytic philosopher' sometimes refers to the sort of philosophy done by people who aspire to approach philosophical problems in the same careful and clear-headed way as Frege."
**32. The claim that one can know something only by being causally affected by it (e.g., Fodor's position regarding knowledge of mathematical truths) is absurd in the extreme.**
> "I personally regard JK as being absurd in the extreme."
**33. The fact that 1+1=2 is non-spatiotemporal; nothing outside space-time can bear causal relations to anything.**
> "The fact it describes must therefore be non-spatiotemporal. Nothing outside of space-time can bear any causal relation to anything. Therefore, JK is wrong."
**34. The dispute over causal theories of knowledge is not linguistic—it concerns whether an agreed-upon meaning is true.**

> "In any case, the dispute between those who accept JK and those who reject it has nothing to do with language. It's agreed what JK means. What isn't agreed is whether the thing that it's agreed to mean is true."
**35. No philosophical assertions are empirical; observation cannot tell you whether one statement is inconsistent with another.**

> "No philosophical assertions are empirical. Philosophy analyzes the categories in terms of which we think about the world... Since observation can't tell one whether one statement is inconsistent with another, philosophical assertions are non-empirical."
**36. The question of whether law requires morality (legal positivism vs. anti-positivism) is to be resolved through logical, not empirical, analysis.**

> "What analytic philosophers of law, such as positivist H.L.A. Hart (1907–1992) and anti-positivist Ronald Dworkin (1931–), do agree about is that LM is to be resolved on the basis of logical analysis."
**37. Logical positivism (LP) holds that meaningful statements are either tautologies or empirical.**
> "LP says that any meaningful statement is either a tautology or is empirical."
**38. LP is self-refuting: it is neither a tautology nor empirically verifiable, so by its own criterion it is meaningless.**
> "Thus, LP is neither an empirical truth nor a tautology. It is thus a counterexample to itself and is therefore false."
**39. There are non-empirical truths that have nothing to do with anyone's linguistic practices.**
> "We've seen that, contrary to what LP says, there are non-empirical truths that have nothing to do with anyone's linguistic practices."
**40. Strictly observational grounds cannot support theoretical statements like Newton's physics directly—only in conjunction with specific factual claims.**

> "By itself NT doesn't make any predictions or otherwise have observable consequences... Thus, taken by itself, NT isn't confirmable. What is confirmable isn't NT, but NT plus statements describing specific matters of fact."
**41. Wittgenstein's acknowledgment that the Tractatus is meaningless by its own standards is self-contradictory; to understand something is to see its meaning.**

> "So far as they aren't trivial, these magisterial words are false. To understand something is to see its meaning. Therefore, anything that is understood has a meaning. So Wittgenstein's words, if understood, have a meaning, and Wittgenstein is therefore contradicting himself in saying that those who understand his words will see that they're meaningless."
**42. Empiricism is self-refuting: if true, there are no grounds for believing it; if there are grounds, it is false.**

> "Thus, so far as empiricism is correct, there are no grounds for believing it correct; and so far as there are such grounds, empiricism is false... Therefore, empiricism, if true, is false; therefore it's false."
**43. Russell's argument against naïve realism ("if true, is false; therefore false") rests on spurious reasoning—we do observe external objects, not merely effects upon ourselves.**

> "Though eloquently stated, this argument consists of spurious reasoning for a false conclusion. In observing the paper-weight on my desk, I'm not observing some effect of the stone upon myself: I'm observing the stone itself."
**44. The greenness, hardness, and coldness of physics are identical with those of daily observation; physics tells us what these properties are.**

> "This is false. Physics has a lot to say about greenness, hardness, and coldness that commonsense does not. But that's very different from saying that the coldness we feel, the greenness we see, etc., aren't the greenness, coldness, and hardness of physics. Physics tells us what it is for something to have the properties we know them to have through sight, touch, etc."
**45. The concept of confirmation is incoherent unless non-empirical knowledge is granted (Goodman's grue argument).**
> "But we'll now see that the concept of confirmation is an incoherent one unless it's granted that there is nonempirical knowledge and, therefore, that confirmationalism is incoherent."
**46. Induction does not have a strictly observational basis; there must be non-observational grounds for preferring certain properties over others in inductive inference.**

> "Contrary to what that argument tacitly assumes, induction does not have strictly observational basis... This means that, if any inductions are better than any others, we must have legitimate but at least partly nonobservational grounds for believing that, when making inductive inferences, certain properties (e.g., green) are relevant and others (e.g., grue) are not."
**47. It is utterances, not sentences per se, that are tautologies—tautologousness depends on how the auditor learned the meanings of expressions.**
> "In this section we'll see that it is utterances of sentences, not sentences per se, that are tautologies."
**48. One knows the meanings of expressions descriptively; two different descriptions can pick out the same thing.**

> "This story illustrates some deeply important facts that are in the philosophy of language. First, one knows the meanings of expressions descriptively... Two very different descriptions can pick out some one thing (cf. 'the third U.S. President' and 'the President responsible for the Louisiana Purchase')."
**49. All entailment is not formal entailment (contra Wittgenstein's Tractatus).**

> "There are some qualifications to this, as we'll see in a moment, but none that redound to the credit of Wittgenstein's point... There are infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one. So Wittgenstein's allegation that all entailments are formal entailment is not feasible."
**50. "Brown is a circle" entails "Brown is a two-dimensional figure," but this is not a formal entailment—it is a non-tautologous, non-empirical truth.**

> "(12) doesn't say anything about the spatiotemporal world. (12) is logically true; its truth is guaranteed by the structures of the concepts composing it. Unlike (11), (12) isn't a tautology. Therefore, it's a non-tautologous, non-empirical truth. Thus, there are non-formal entailments."
**51. The concept of a logically perfect language is incoherent.**
> "In any case, the concept of a logically perfect language is not a coherent one. It isn't possible for everything about a sentence's meaning to be reflected in its grammar."
**52. If a logically perfect language existed, it would be expressively inferior to natural languages.**
> "And if per impossibile there did exist a logically perfect language, it would be expressively inferior to English, Arabic, and every other natural language."
**53. For each analytic truth a logically perfect language could express, there would be infinitely many it could not express.**
> "A consequence is that, for each analytic truth that a logically perfect language can express, there are infinitely many that it cannot express."
**54. Knowing that a formal entailment is valid requires knowing that some informal entailment is valid; there are infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one.**

> "The only way to know that some formal entailment is valid is to know that some informal entailment is valid... There are, quite literally, infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one."
**55. There cannot be strictly observation-based knowledge that an object's length is given by an irrational number (Hempel's argument).**

> "It follows that, if an object's length is given by an irrational number, that fact cannot be known directly on the basis of measurement. It therefore follows that there is no strictly observation-based way to know that y's length equals x's multiplied by √2."
**56. Modern physics depends on assumptions (that magnitudes can assume irrational values) for which there cannot be strictly observational grounds.**

> "Thus, it must be assumed that, at certain junctures, the velocities, lengths, masses, etc., of objects are sometimes given by irrational numbers. But there cannot, as we've seen, be strictly observational grounds for believing that a given object's length is √2 meters."
**57. Strict empiricism is inconsistent with the fact that modern physics is a source of knowledge.**
> "This means that strict empiricism is inconsistent with the obvious fact that modern physics is a source of knowledge."
**58. Euclid's axioms (1)–(5) are statement-forms, not statements proper, and some interpretations of them are false.**

> "We'll use the expression '(1)-(5)' to refer to the conjunction of (1) and (2) and (3), etc... One would think that (1)-(5) is correct. But this turned out not to be so. It turned out that (1)-(5) is a statement-form, not a statement proper, and that (1)-(5) therefore isn't true or false. It also turned out that some of its instances are false."
**59. The parallel postulate is not true or false of anything—it is a statement-form.**

> "According to many, this shows that the parallel postulate isn't true of every possible space. This isn't what it shows. The parallel postulate isn't true or false of anything. It's a statement-form, not a statement, and statement-forms aren't true or false of anything."
**60. Arithmetical truth cannot be formalized: any formal characterization of arithmetic is either inconsistent or incomplete.**

> "It turned out that this is not possible. This means that any formal characterization of arithmetic is either inconsistent (i.e., it entails a contradiction), or incomplete (i.e., there is some arithmetical truth that is not a consequence of it)."
**61. The possible worlds analysis of counterfactuals (Lewis, Kment, Stalnaker) is completely preposterous.**
> "I find this analysis completely preposterous."
**62. We don't know anything about other universes; any knowledge of them would be parasitic on knowledge of counterfactual truths.**

> "We don't know anything about other universes, let alone whether Smith and Kennedy exist in them or, therefore, what their situations there are. Anything we do know about such universes is parasitic on our knowledge of counterfactual truths like K and S."
**63. Counterfactuals are grammatical variants of ordinary causal or logical statements.**
> "The right analysis of counterfactuals, I would suggest, is to see them as grammatical variants of garden variety causal or logical statements."
**64. "Someone" is not in the same semantic category as "John" or "Ethel"—it does not refer to an individual.**
> "What all this shows is that 'someone' isn't in the same category as 'John' and 'Ethel.' It doesn't function in the same way, even though, given its grammatical function, one would expect it to."
**65. "Someone smokes" does not attribute the property of smoking to a non-specific individual; it states that the property of being a smoker is instantiated.**

> "What SS is saying, as Frege made clear, is that the characteristic—or as analytic philosophers put it, the property—of being a smoker is instantiated. SS is making a statement, not about some non-specific individual, but about a very specific property, and it's saying of this property that it's instantiated."
**66. There is no such thing as an "ambiguous person" or "non-specific entity"—to posit such things is to twist reality to conform to grammatical assumptions.**

> "The wrong way to react to that fact is to twist reality to make it conform to our assumption that 'someone,' being grammatically comparable to 'John,' must refer to something... But then we're then stuck with the absurd thesis that there is some non-specific entity in the world."
**67. The word "someone" is not ambiguous; it has one meaning.**
> "That's false. 'Someone' isn't ambiguous; it isn't like the word 'dumb.' SS has one meaning."
**68. Analytic philosophers solve problems by clarifying statements, not by ontologizing (positing entities not previously believed to exist).**

> "As a general rule, analytic philosophers do not try to solve philosophical problems by 'ontologizing'—that is, by positing an entity, or class of entities, not previously believed to exist. They try to solve them by clarifying statements."
**69. When analytic philosophers do ontologize, they posit only abstract, non-spatiotemporal entities—never spatiotemporal denizens like persons or tables.**

> "But, whenever this happens, the 'entity' being posted is never a denizen of the spatiotemporal world; the thing that's posited is never a person or a table or a mountain or a monster. It's always an abstract object of some kind."
**70. Properties exist; their existence is validated by obviously true statements (e.g., "Bob and Sally are both intelligent").**

> "For example, given the premise that Bob and Sally are both humans who are intelligent, it follows that there exist characteristics—or, to use the word preferred by analytic philosophers, properties—that Bob and Sally have in common, and from this it follows that properties exist."
**71. Properties are not identical with spatiotemporal entities; you will never encounter intelligence per se in space-time.**
> "But although you may encounter many instances of intelligence, you'll never encounter intelligence per se and it would make no sense to assign any spatiotemporal location to it."
**72. The essence of the mental is intentionality (non-derivative representationality), as Brentano held.**
> "According to Franz Brentano (1838–1917), the essence of the mental is intentionality... So Brentano's thesis is that for something to be mental is for it to be non-derivatively representational."
**73. Perception is description—seeing Larry involves seeing that various properties are instantiated.**

> "The solution to this problem lies in the fact that perception is description... Seeing Larry involves seeing a thing having various properties—having a certain color, shape, size, position (relative to you), etc. So seeing Larry involves seeing that various properties are instantiated."
**74. Perceptions represent objects by encoding existence-claims that those objects satisfy.**
> "So, yes, your perception does represent Larry. But it represents him by way of encoding an existence-claim that he satisfies."
**75. The content of a perception is given by an existence-claim, not by a semantically simple symbol.**

> "But in no sense-perception of Larry is he represented by some simple, homogenous, non-composite cipher. So far as he is perceived, Larry is represented as having these or those properties... Thus, the content of your perception of Larry is given by some existence-claim."
**76. Hallucinations are representational not because they pick out non-existent objects, but because they encode false existence-claims.**

> "The important point is that, although it was hallucinatory, your visual experience encoded an existence-claim and, in so doing, gave you a message and was therefore representational. It wasn't representational in the sense that there was some thing that it picked out and, for that reason, represented."
**77. Thoughts about non-existent things (e.g., an even prime greater than two) involve thinking false existence-claims.**

> "The same thing is true of thoughts about the non-existent. When you think about some non-existent number—for example, an even prime greater than two—there isn't some mathematically impossible entity that you're cognitively locking onto. What's going on is that you're thinking some false existence-claim."
**78. Wittgenstein's view that philosophical problems arise only when sentences are misused is incorrect.**
> "But in both of them, Wittgenstein insists that that philosophical problems arise when, and only when, sentences are misused... But this position is incorrect."

**79. Wittgenstein's Tractatus holds that philosophical statements violate hidden syntactic rules; the Investigations holds they result from using words in non-standard ways—both positions are wrong.**

> "In the TLP, Wittgenstein contends that all philosophical problems result from a failure to understand the syntactic rules of the languages we use... In the Philosophical Investigations... he denies that such misuses involve violations of hidden syntactic rules, and instead says that such misuses consist exclusively in one's using words in ways in which they are not ordinarily used."
**80. One cannot learn about concepts by studying word usage unless one can already grasp the concept independently of the word.**

> "Given any expression E and any concept C, an obvious extension of this argument shows that one can't learn about C by studying E unless one can grasp C, and can therefore examine it, without E's help. Thus, Wittgenstein is simply wrong to contend that one learns about concepts by learning about how the corresponding words are used."
**81. Wittgenstein's thesis that "meaning is use" is incoherent.**
> "This contention is incoherent on many levels."
**82. If two expressions could only differ in meaning by being used differently, then any two sentences that have never been used would have the same meaning—which is absurd.**

> "Also, given any natural language, there are infinitely many sentences belonging to it that have never been used. The thesis that sentences have the same meaning iff they're used in the same way has the absurd consequence that any two sentences that haven't been used before have the same meaning."
**83. Conceptual role semantics (CRS)—the thesis that two sentences have the same meaning iff used the same way—is indefensible.**
> "In any case, CRS is indefensible."
**84. Someone who utters a sentence does so because she knows semantic rules assign a certain proposition to those words and she wishes to express that proposition.**

> "So far as she isn't misspeaking or randomly barking out noises, anyone who says 'it's hot out' or 'hace much calor,' or any other sentence, does so because she knows that existing semantic rules assign a certain proposition to those words and she wishes to put that proposition into words."
**85. Carnap's view that for a lecture to concern triangles is for the word "triangle" to occur in the lecture is false.**

> "Carnap's view is false. Many a lecture that doesn't contain the word 'triangle' concerns triangles. (Think of all the mathematics lectures given in Japanese, Swedish, and Arabic. How often does the word 'triangle' occur in them?)"
**86. The very essence of logical positivism is the denial of meaning (propositions).**

> "The distinction between the word 'triangle' and the corresponding meaning is one that Carnap couldn't countenance without ceasing to be a logical positivist. The very essence of logical positivism is the denial of meaning."
**87. It is not up to us whether meanings (propositions) are correct, even though it is up to us what our symbols mean.**
> "We can use words in any way that we like... But whatever meaning we end up assigning to those words, it's not up to us whether that meaning is correct."
**88. Logical truths are never sentences; they are always propositions.**
> "Thus, it is always propositions, and never sentences, that are logically true."
**89. Propositions are never conventionally true; linguistic conventions are known empirically, but what those conventions express is not itself empirical.**
> "But no proposition is true by convention. It's up to us what our symbols mean. But it's not up to us whether those meanings are correct."
**90. Logical positivists were unanimous in denying the existence of propositions and meanings generally.**
> "It should be pointed out that logical positivists were unanimous in denying the existence of propositions and of meanings generally."

**91. Sentences like "the universe is a perfect unity" are not meaningless because they are non-empirical; they are meaningless because key terms are undefined—they are statement-forms, not statements.**

> "'Statements' such as 'the universe is a perfect unity,' 'the nothing nothings,' and so on, aren't really statements at all. They're statement-forms. (i) is obviously supposed to attribute some property to the universe. But since this property isn't identified, (i) contains an undefined term and therefore says nothing."
**92. Once undefined terms are defined, previously "meaningless" sentences become meaningful and true or false.**
> "Once that term is defined, a meaningful statement results."
**93. A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object; it is meaningless if it does not attribute any property to anything.**
> "A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object. A sentence S is meaningful if, for some object x and some property phi, S says that x has phi."
**94. Any non-compound sentence either says of some individual that it has some property or says that two or more individuals are interrelated in a certain way.**

> "Any non-compound sentence (i.e., any sentence that doesn't consist of other sentences) either says of some individual that it has some property or it says that two more individuals are interrelated in a certain way."
**95. All sentences (relational, compound, negative, quantified) can be reduced to the form ‹x has phi›.**
> "We have thus established that any given sentence S is equivalent to some sentence having the form ‹x has phi.›"
**96. The picture theory of meaning—that sentences are "pictures" of the facts they describe—is either trivially true or incoherent.**
> "What does he mean? Maybe he means that sentences are picture-like in that they, like pictures, represent facts. But in that case what Wittgenstein is saying is completely and utterly trivial."
**97. If the picture theory means that sentences share structural features with the facts they describe, it is dubiously coherent.**
> "Maybe Wittgenstein is saying that sentences and the facts they describe share structural features. But this claim is of dubious coherence."
**98. Wittgenstein's claim that "what can be shown, cannot be said" is obviously false.**

> "Wittgenstein's assertion that 'what can be shown, cannot be said' is obviously false. I tell you that I can do fifty push-ups. (I say 'I can do fifty push-ups.') You don't believe me. So I show you that I can do fifty push-ups."
**99. Contrary to Wittgenstein, we can identify the logical forms of our own utterances; we do it whenever we put the meanings of words into words.**

> "In any case, contrary to what Wittgenstein says, we can identify the logical forms of our own utterances. To identify the logical form of a statement is simply to make it clear what it means. We can do this. We do it all the time. We do it whenever we put the meanings of words into words."
**100. No language can state all of its own semantic rules—there is a proof of this.**

> "But neither the English language, nor any other, can state all of its own semantic rules. Here's why... We're forced to reject this obvious truth if we grant the supposition that the English language can express each of its own semantic rules. Therefore, the English language cannot state all of its own semantic rules."
**101. The claim that truth is indefinable is false if it means we cannot say what it is for a proposition to be true; it is true if it means no language can state all of its own semantic rules.**
> "It is often said that truth is indefinable... (a) is false. (See Chapter 3.) But (b) is true."
**102. The sub-disciplines of philosophy (mind, language, epistemology, logic, metaphysics, science, ethics, political philosophy, religion, formal logic) overlap considerably.**
> "It should be kept in mind that these sub-disciplines overlap a great deal."
**103. The question "do we think in words?" belongs to both the philosophy of mind and the philosophy of language.**
> "So, for example, the question 'do we think in words?' belongs to the philosophy of mind and to the philosophy of language."
**104. Philosophical logic studies bearing-relations among sentences and propositions.**
> "This discipline studies bearing-relations holding among sentences and propositions (sentence-meanings)."
**105. Metaphysics studies the nature of possibility, necessity, causal relations, identity, and the conditions something must meet to exist.**

> "This discipline studies the nature of possibility and necessity, of causal relations between objects. It also studies the nature of identity and the conditions that something must meet in order to exist."
**106. The philosophy of science studies the logical structure of scientific endeavor and its results.**
> "This discipline studies the logical structure of scientific endeavor and of its results."
**107. There may be a fundamental difference between explanations in the physical sciences and explanations in the psychological sciences.**
> "Is there a fundamental difference between explanations in the physical sciences and explanation in the psychological sciences?"
**108. Whether a system is deterministic or not may depend on how it is described—determinism may be a logical property of statements, not of events (Nagel's view).**

> "Determinism is a logical property of statements, in Nagel's view, not of the events they describe. A consequence is that a given domain may be deterministic with respect to one method of describing it, but indeterministic with respect to some other method of describing it."
**109. Formal logic studies formal truth and attempts to formalize informal analytic truth insofar as possible.**
> "This discipline studies formal truth... Formal logic tries to formalize informal analytic truth, so far as that's possible to do so, and to say when it isn't possible, so far as it isn't."
**110. A sentence is formally true if every sentence of the same form is true.**
> "A sentence is formally true if every sentence of the same form is true."
**111. Open-sentences (statement-forms) are neither true nor false; only their instances (when variables are replaced with constants) are true or false.**
> "An open sentence is a sentence-like expression that contains a free variable and is thus neither true nor false."
**112. Mathematical logicians try to identify open-sentences that are true under all their interpretations, thereby formalizing analytic truth.**

> "Formal logicians aspire to identify open-sentences that are true under all their interpretations, since it is only to the extent that they can do this that they can formalize analytic truth, which is their main objective."
**113. Some classes of true statements (e.g., arithmetical statements) that one would expect to be formalizable turn out not to be—arithmetical truth cannot be formalized.**

> "There are some classes of true statements that one would expect to be formalizable but turn out not to be. The class of arithmetical statements ('1 + 2 = 3,' '2 × 9 = 18,' etc.) is an example. In other words, arithmetical truth cannot be formalized."
---KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT FOR FREE WILL AND OTHER PAPERS
POSITION STATEMENT KUCZYNSKI COLLECTED IMPORTANT PAPERS
=== ORIGINALISM ===
The expression "the intentions of the framers" denotes an idealization, not an empirical actuality, since the various framers had numerically and qualitatively different minds.
When the word "they" is part of an expression meant to denote a collective attitude, it denotes an idealization rather than an empirical reality.
Originalism is exceedingly dubious if the term "intentions" is understood in purely individualistic, psychological terms.
If originalism is to hold water, "the intentions of the framers" must refer to the intentions of some kind of collective entity.
The intentions of the framers cannot be understood strictly in terms of the psychologies of the framers taken individually.

The originalist position collapses into circularity: Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of the intentions of the framers, but the intentions of the framers are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.
An idealization is by definition something that has no precise counterpart in the spatiotemporal world.

When discussing what Jefferson would have said about constitutional issues, we are not making an empirical statement about what the actual Jefferson would have said, but rather an a priori proposition about what he should have said given his values.

The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use a counterfactual to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but he cannot run the counterfactual until he has identified those values.

Jefferson's values are definable independently of any views of Constitutional interpretation, but the expression "Jefferson's values" itself denotes an idealization as opposed to a psychological reality.
Like many complex human beings, Jefferson had many values, and while some may have been fair-minded and egalitarian, others may have been retrograde and misogynist.

When we say that Jefferson was not being "true to his values," the word "his" doesn't denote Thomas Jefferson the human being but rather an idealization of Jefferson purged of his 18th century prejudices.
Even the finest minds are marred by ugly biases.

When we talk about what Jefferson would have said, we are talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said—one who didn't suffer from the cultural limitations and random neuroses that mar even the best of minds.
Once we start dealing with an idealization of Jefferson's psyche, as opposed to his actual psyche, we have replaced empirical propositions about psychology with a priori propositions about values.
=== BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER ===
People with borderline personality disorder have two distinct, simultaneously operative psychological "operating systems"—one appropriately adult and sane, the other infantile in nature.
One part of the BPD person's mind remained "stuck" or "fixated" at an early phase of life, usually very early childhood, while the other part advanced to maturity.
The fixation in BPD typically results from a trauma, usually sexual molestation.
People with BPD oscillate between their adult and infantile psychological integrations.
The rapid oscillation between two modalities makes BPD individuals appear to be lying or "playing games," when in fact they are shifting between two distinct and incongruent worldviews.
People with BPD are not psychopaths, despite sometimes acting in entitled, limitlessly self-serving narcissistic ways.

The difference between BPD and psychopathy: the psychopath is simply a phony who sometimes puts on a mask of sanity and decency, while the BPD person is genuinely two-sided, with neither side being a mask.
The preferred psychological defense mechanism in BPD is splitting rather than repression.
The BPD personality-structure is itself the result of splitting.

Repression involves having a single psychological architecture and shoving incompatible conceits into the unconscious, while splitting involves shifting between one's adult side and one's infantile side.
The normal person's psyche keeps its infantilism in the abyss of the unconscious, while the BPD person's psyche keeps infantilisms in a concurrently operative sphere of mental activity.
The essence of borderline personality disorder is that splitting takes the place of repression.
When the psychopath acts non-psychopathically, it is because he is just acting; when the BPD person acts non-psychopathically, it is because she is being true to one side of her personality.
When the BPD person acts psychopathically, it is because she is regressing and her infantile side is dominating, not because a mask has fallen.
=== GROUP PSYCHOLOGY ===
Most people, including most psychologists, wrongly assume that group psychology is to be understood in terms of individual psychology.
The standard view that individuals have self-directed drives that are somehow diverted in group contexts cannot be reconciled with the incredibly high degree of conformism exhibited by people.
The deference given by people to convention, pre-existing custom, and fleeting but powerful fads cannot be explained in terms of fear of others alone.

Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in the behavior of collectives, it is hard to believe that collectives are merely the result of individuals pursuing their respective paths.
The collective is the primary thing, biologically speaking, and there is an illusion of individual choice and indeed of individualism per se.

Individual cells can be better understood if we recognize that they individually try to survive, flourish, and reproduce only to the extent that their doing so is necessary for the collectives formed thereby to survive, flourish, and reproduce.
Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
Person-individualism can be explained in terms of person-collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
Bona fide individuals—geniuses who think for themselves—can be seen as limiting cases of collectives, as collectives of one, or as rogue actors with an unusual office within a collective.
The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong.
It is very hard to explain group behavior on the assumption that collectives represent averages of the behaviors of so many self-contained existentialist autonomous deciders.

Outside of contexts involving immediate threats to physical well-being or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores to be accounted for by the hypothesis that collectives are indeed collectives of bona fide individuals.
=== FINANCIAL REGULATION ===
Before the 1929 Stock Market Crash, the nation's financial system was highly unregulated, leading to improprieties that caused the Crash.
The Fed responded to the Stock Market Crash by tightening monetary policy, which exacerbated the situation and led to a full-blown economic depression.
Glass-Steagall prohibited commercial banks from functioning as investment banks, thereby preventing banks from using customer funds to finance their own ventures.
The repeal of Glass-Steagall in 1999 and the deregulation of the derivatives market in 2004 eliminated the firewalls put in place after the 1929 Crash.
The 2001 Dot Bomb Crash resulted from banks investing in substandard tech startups, and the 2008 Housing Crash resulted from banks investing in worthless derivatives contracts.
A derivative is a contract whose value is a function of the value of some other security, and most derivatives are highly leveraged, highly risky, and difficult to value.
The price of a home tends to stay close to its value, but with securities there is very little short-term relationship between price and value—the two can diverge without limit instantaneously.
When real-estate debts were bundled into financial securities like MBS's, the market could make them far more valuable than the underlying assets, and could do so in hours.
Once mortgages were securitized, investment banks had enormous incentives to drive up the number of home loans issued, regardless of the quality of those loans.
Bubbles can only last so long; eventually prices and values converge when demand fails to keep pace with supply.
The 2008 crisis was really two distinct crises: a housing crisis that decreased wealth and a banking crisis that diminished credit.
Economies depend on credit as much as they do on wealth; when businesses cannot borrow, they fail and the economy fails.
The Volcker Rule does not categorically prohibit banks from engaging in proprietary trading but requires that they match customer funds with their own funds when doing so.
The Volcker Rule prohibits banks from partnering with hedge funds and private equity firms to limit the extent to which large banks can endanger themselves and the market.
The Fed's role as a regulatory agency is ambiguous, since unlike every other financial regulatory agency, it is partly made up of the very entities it is supposed to regulate.
Given that three banks own over 75% of the Fed's shares, the Fed has at best a serious conflict of interest and at worst has no existence separate from the banks that own it.
Financial regulation has done a great deal of good and very little harm; financial deregulation has done a great deal of harm and very little good.
The Fed is in the practice of managing self-generated crises.
We cannot expect banks to self-regulate, and we therefore cannot expect the Fed to self-regulate to the extent that it is owned by banks.
In the United States, financial regulations have decentralized access to capital, keeping the economy going, while financial deregulation has hindered the economy by centralizing access to capital.
Even by the lights of a radical free marketeer, financial regulation has been a success because it has decentralized access to capital.
=== SORITES PARADOX ===
The Sorites paradox can be solved while holding on to all the laws of classical logic, contrary to most attempts that reject the law of bivalence.
Given any predicate that generates a Sorites-paradox, significant use of that predicate is actually elliptical for a relational statement.
A significant token of "Bob is poor" means "Bob is poor compared to x" for some value of x.
Once a value of x is supplied, a definite cutoff line between having and not having the paradox-generating predicate is supplied, which neutralizes the inductive step.
Not all properties generate Sorites-type arguments; only properties that can be had to varying degrees generate them.
Binary properties—those that do not admit of comparatives—do not generate Sorites arguments.

Sorites-sentences are context-sensitive; the sentence "Bob is fast" makes a false statement if Bob is a cheetah with a top speed of 30 mph but a true statement if Bob is a turtle with a top speed of 2 mph.
Bob cannot be wealthy simpliciter; he must be wealthy compared to some standard or class.
Different tokens of "x is smart" involve comparison to different standards and thus express what are, strictly speaking, different propositions.
The term "tall" has the same meaning in "Bob is tall" as it has in "Bob is tall compared to Fred," and therefore "tall" is really elliptical for "tall compared to __."
The meaning of a predicate is intimately bound up with the number of argument places it has; predicates of different degrees ipso facto have different meanings.
Being "absolutely non-wealthy" involves just as much reference to some standard of comparison as being "comparatively non-wealthy"—it means being non-wealthy relative to every standard.
Relativization to a standard is the essence of measurement; to measure is to compare with something taken as a standard.
Degree-statements, even highly generic ones like "x is acidic to some positive degree," always presuppose some benchmark.
=== LIBET EXPERIMENT AND FREE WILL ===
Libet's experiment shows that the conscious events people believe to be their decisions are not the operative intentions—consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
The readiness potential (RP) is obviously the proximal psychological cause of the action; therefore W (the conscious awareness) is not the intention but an awareness of the intention.
By the time W happens, the RP is almost complete; if W is part of the intention, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function.
W is not a mere epiphenomenon because consciousness of one's intentions necessarily affects subsequent thought and behavior.
The evidence suggests W is not a part of the operative intention but rather an awareness of it; W happens very late in the process.
If W were the decision responsible for the finger-movement, the graph would inflect upwards after W, not fail to inflect or inflect negatively.
W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are by their nature decisive causes, and W is not decisive.
Libet's veto experiment provides evidence that W can at least put the brakes on an already-initiated action, even if it cannot initiate actions.
Libet's experiment concerns a subset of actions—real-time sensory-motor engagements with one's environment—but these are actions where consciousness is presumably most heavily involved.

Standing intentions (enduring psychological structures like "my intention to create a trading platform") demonstrably cannot be constituents of consciousness; one can be conscious of them, but they are not themselves constituents of consciousness.
Libet's experiment shows that we do not have "conscious free will"; our decisions, even those governing real-time responses to the environment, are not constituents of consciousness.
The .2 second delay between intention and awareness is very possibly not mere "tape-delay" but reflects W's function as an action-monitor rather than action-instigator.
Follow-up studies using fMRI show that relevant RPs began much earlier than Libet thought, sometimes preceding W by as much as 10 seconds.
What we believe to be choices initiated in consciousness are not initiated in consciousness; they are initiated prior to any conscious awareness of them.
It is unclear how Libet's results bear on "whether we have free will," but that is because the concept of free will is unclear, not because the experimental findings are unclear.
Philosophers have responded very conservatively and defensively to Libet's findings, doing more to obfuscate than to illuminate their significance.
Indeterminism threatens freedom; determinism seems to be a prerequisite for freedom.
Thoughts that totally lacked a causal basis in a person's pre-existing psychological structures would be mere intrusions, not exercises of agency.
We only have freedom to the extent that the world, including ourselves, is deterministic.
Neuroscience does not merely show us how intentions and beliefs are physiologically implemented; it gives us counterintuitive information about them.
Libet's experimental data cannot be dismissed as margin-of-error; the subject established the time of W by coordinating it with a clock making one full rotation every 500 ms.
The distinction between proximal and distal intentions is valid, but distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions.
The actions studied in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of bona fide actions—non-automatic, non-reflexive, "freely made" actions—not quasi-reflexes.
The RP obviously causes the finger-movement; either that or it is temporally coincident with whatever the cause is—either way, W is not the operative intention.
The idea that we "just know" we have free will is straightforwardly question-begging; free will, if it exists, is a form of causation, and what causes what is always an open empirical question.

Compatibilism says you are free even though determined, but Libet's experiment shows not so much that you are determined as that you are on the sidelines—by the time you appear, the decision has been made.
What is ominous about the Libet Experiment is not that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours—they are yours to behold but not to make.
Libet's results are even more radical than Freud's: Freud regarded consciousness as a weak but genuine central authority; Libet shows it to be a mere spectator.
All developed philosophical positions on human agency assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices; Libet's experiment shows this to be false.
One purpose of consciousness may be to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world.
W, though not the cause of a particular intention, may implicitly green-light future similar intentions—telling the relevant part of the mind to carry on apace.
The "illusion of free choice"—experiencing decision-approval as decision-making—may be a small price to pay for gains in cognitive efficiency.
=== BERKELEY AND ANTI-FOUNDATIONALISM ===
Wilfred Sellars destroyed "the myth of the given" and began a revolution in epistemology, but Berkeley made essentially the same points two hundred years earlier.
The foundationalist picture holds that no empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality—a given perception can do that on its own.

Sellars is not denying that external realities are made known to us through sense-perceptions, but attacking the idea that perception does so without the cooperation of preexisting empirical knowledge.

There are two senses in which knowledge is not "given": its existence presupposes a background of empirical knowledge, and the sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge does not constitute knowledge of anything.
The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or "given"; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge.
Berkeley's argument for anti-foundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars' version.
What ultimately endows visual sensations with information regarding distances is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants.
Your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the size or distance of an object; what does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge.
One's visual experience, taken by itself and stripped of contextualization, doesn't tell one whether one is seeing a tree-size pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.
It is only "past experience" that teaches us that a particular appearance betokens a square object rather than a diamond-shaped one.
Berkeley has a definite answer to Molyneux's question: a man born blind given sight would not know from visual perceptions alone whether he was seeing a round, oval, or square object.
When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning, but your auditory experience apprises you of significance only with the help of background knowledge.
Your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence.

When a person's face reddens in a particular way indicating shame, your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the shame; background knowledge of how emotions are given bodily expression is at work.
No sensory experience by itself tells one anything; any such experience must be put in the context of background knowledge to bear any determinate message about the external world.

No sensory experience is foundational; empirical knowledge is obtained by putting current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and previously obtained empirical knowledge.

Sellars only gives one example of how sensory experiences need background knowledge (perception of color under non-standard conditions), while Berkeley's argument directly applies to virtually every perceptible property under standard conditions.

Sellars doesn't really explain how representational mental entities (perceptions) are forged out of non-representational mental entities (raw feels, qualia, sensations), but Berkeley goes to great lengths to show this.
Berkeley provides a non-metaphorical way of interpreting the metaphors that dominate contemporary anti-foundationalism (the "arc" or "web" of knowledge).
Two problems arise on Berkeley-Sellars anti-foundationalism: how any belief manages to be justified, and how anything representational arises out of what is not representational.

The problem of how perceptions arise out of non-representational sensations is more fundamental than the problem of justification, because until we have perceptions, the problem of justification doesn't arise.
Standard conditions of perception are an idealization; no conditions are really standard—if we could set up a distortion-free situation, it would not be typical.
What Sellars says about Bob's intake of color-facts in a tie-shop with unusual lighting is true of our intake of color-facts in general, and of shape-facts, size-facts, distance-facts, and so on.

A ten-foot stop-sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as a 1,000-foot stop-sign looked at from 10,000 feet away; one knows the approximate height only through background information.
In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness—to the point of having no representational content.

The appearance given off by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking object; contextual information (knowing that people don't shrink) disambiguates the visual experience.
=== ADDITIONAL PHILOSOPHICAL POSITIONS ===
The concept of "free will" is so unclear that difficulties in applying experimental findings to it reflect problems with the concept, not with the findings.

Philosophers seldom ask "What does the Libet experiment show?" but instead ask "What does the experiment show about free will?"—the second question concedes too much validity to assumptions that the experiment calls into question.
Nothing is gained, and much is lost, by trying to press experimental results into the service of a pre-existing philosophical agenda.
The position that pre-W brain activity is merely an "urge" that W converts into a genuine intention is question-begging; W does not have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement.
If W happened at the very beginning or peak of the readiness potential slope, it could be a decision; but W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.
The comparison between knowledge of free will and the cogito is misconceived; the cogito registers an analytic truth whose negation is incoherent, but the assertion of free will is not trivial.
Actions studied in Libet's experiment were set up to maximize the role of consciousness; the subject was wide awake, given explicit instructions, and could push the button whenever he wanted.
The more deliberation and "rational reflection" are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious.
Philosophers have done little beyond playing skeptic with Libet's data, using standards of proof by which there would be no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer.
We stand to learn about the mind by investigating models consistent with Libet's data; we do not stand to learn by insisting that Libet "must" be wrong.
Libet's experiment represents an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for philosophy.
If it turns out that Libet's data is spurious, so be it; in the meantime, we should accept it and try to model it rather than reflexively dismissing it.
The experiments in question do not merely support but establish that consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
Consciousness may serve to approve or disapprove of decisions already made rather than to make decisions, with disapproval having a directive role for future intentions.
There is no experimental data to support the claim that Libet's results only apply to "low-level" actions that fail to engage rationality or agency.

Any episode of taking in information about the external world—any perception of height, speed, shape, or color—involves the cooperation of contextual or background information.KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT EMPIRICISM AND THE FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY
POSITION STATEMENT KUCZYNSKI EMPIRICISM AND THE FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY
Empiricism is fundamentally incompatible with a scientific psychology.
There exists subpersonal thought that underlies conscious, preconscious, and repressed ideation.
Subpersonal mentation is inherently intelligent, whereas personal/conscious mentation is inherently unintelligent.
Consciousness qua consciousness is capable only of iconic (pictorial) representation.
Concepts are not constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.
Berkeley conflated images with concepts, using "idea" to refer to both.
Symbol-manipulations facilitate ratiocinative operations, but anything one can think with symbols can be thought without them.
The meaning of a complex expression cannot be directly determined by convention.
There is a fundamental distinction between object-awareness and truth-awareness (proposition-awareness).
Creatures can be merely object-aware (MOCs) or proposition-aware (PACs); all truth-aware creatures are object-aware, but not vice versa.
Desires are identical with judgments concerning what would bring pleasure or gratification.
Intentions are judgments, not desires.
Davidson's identification of intentions with one's strongest desires is false.
Higher-order desires as described by Frankfurt are often actually judgments, not desires.
Agency is identical with rationality—specifically, applied rationality deployed in accordance with one's values.
Rational agents are fundamentally different from mere reflex machines or reagents.
The self is a rationality-constituted superstructure whose original purpose was to ensure the organism's survival but whose developed purpose is self-honing and expanding its powers.
Physiological properties are multiply realizable with respect to microphysical properties.
The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model of scientific explanation is false.
Psychological explanation works through rationalization, identifying causal mechanisms in rational motivations.
A cause can be operative even if its effect was not guaranteed—causation can be probabilistic.
Laws need not be exceptionless regularities to have genuine explanatory value.
Macro-level properties cannot be reduced to microphysical properties.
Perception requires conceptual articulation; it is not mere sensation but articulated sensation.
Introspection is an act of conceptualization, not theoretically innocent reportage.
Husserl's phenomenological bracketing fails because one cannot strip perceptions of their conceptual articulations.
The Dennett-Churchland eliminativist position on mind is untenable.
Perceptual data is as theory-laden as psychological data.
Russell and other logicians were wrong that self-referential sentences are meaningless; such expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
The unconscious mind exists and cannot be understood in strictly empiricist terms.
Repression and rationalization are concepts inherently incompatible with empiricism.
Psychosis involves partial cognitive regression where infantile and adult thought pathologically commingle.
Neurotic people perceive external reality accurately but are blind to their own feelings.
There is a crucial distinction between access-consciousness and consciousness-proper.
Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when it becomes rule-governed through linguistic mediation.
Music transfers subpersonal intelligence to the conscious level, making otherwise imperceptible thought-processes perceptible.
Aesthetic beauty is relational—a property of relations between minds and sounds/objects, not intrinsic to sounds/objects themselves.
Sociopathy is psychological suicide: the destruction of one's value-based psychological architecture.
One can change oneself but cannot change one's self; identity is predetermined, and experience determines only how one is who one is.
Pathological insecurity and pathological grandiosity are two sides of the same coin.
Shame at being wrong is morbid and regressive, as making mistakes is inseparable from the human condition.
Folk-psychology enables rationalization of conscious states but has inherent limitations in explaining psychopathology.
Dreams involve relaxation of maturation-based inhibitions, liberating infantile mental content from the unconscious.
Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness and are knowable only to the extent they are phenomenologized.
It is viciously regressive to suppose that the self carries out the cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.
Science is not about sticking to facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures to restore continuities that observation strips away.
The empiricist's injunction to "stick to the facts" is either a triviality or an absurdity.
Perception cannot self-justify; justification for perception must come from non-empirical, analytic principles.
Rationalizations are moralizations: attempts to make the immoral seem moral.
Sociopaths do not have friends because they do not have values, and a friend is somebody one values.
Now I have enough material. Here are 100 additional positions:
Propositions are non-spatiotemporal entities that consist of properties.
Properties are non-spatiotemporal; they cannot be identified with spatiotemporal entities.
The relata of logical relations are propositions, not sentences.
Logical relations (entailment, confirmation, disconfirmation, incompatibility, neutrality) hold among propositions, not among spatiotemporal entities.
Empiricists must deny the existence of propositions because propositions are non-spatiotemporal.
Psychological propositions do not present facts as being in the same spatial coordinate system as physical propositions.
The relationship between psychology and physiology is even more remote than the relationship between physiology and microphysics.
Hume's skepticism about perception and induction follows correctly from empiricism, which should lead us to reject empiricism rather than accept skepticism.
Scientific thought is not the same as empirical thought; to the extent thought mediates between observations and beliefs, beliefs are not directly supported by observation.
Hume's analysis of causation as mere constant conjunction is false.
We perceive instances of causation directly when we perceive instances of persistence and occupancy.
Any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.
A Hume-world (a world with the same events but no causation) is incoherent because persistence itself requires causal ties.
Space-time position is constituted by causal relations; there is no non-relational way of understanding space-time position.
Events are not constituents of the external world but nominalizations of truths.
Facts and truths are distinct; truths hold in virtue of facts but are not identical with facts.
The distinction between explanatory generalizations of different disciplines lies in the concepts composing them, not in the underlying reality.
Wittgenstein's private language argument fails because the lone speaker of a private language is in no different epistemic position than the English speaker relying on memory.
Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist whose rejection of non-spatiotemporal entities like propositions and concepts follows from his empiricism.
Groups of zombies cannot collectively think; if every member of a group is a zombie, the group itself is without consciousness.
The Argument from Analogy for other minds is valid, contrary to Wittgenstein's objections.
Quine's thesis of the indeterminacy of translation is a desperate measure resulting from his empiricist commitments.
Translation between languages requires reliance on introspection-based knowledge of one's own mental states.
Thinking is not a psychological process in Wittgenstein's sense; propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
Mental imagery can be thought-constitutive, contrary to Wittgenstein's view, when understood in relation to its ratiocinative context.
The deployment of propositional attitudes in problem-solving is not constitutive of consciousness; consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under the car's hood.
Dispositionalism about mental states fails to model the data; mental states must be functioning as such even between bouts of generating consciousness.
Your belief that 1+1=2 is not identical with your dispositions to make certain judgments; it must be actively functioning to explain those dispositions.
Cognitive processes are realized by physiological processes, but psychological relations between physiological events cannot be understood in physiological terms.
Searle's view that mentality is identical with consciousness (MC) is false.
Propositional attitudes are not and cannot be constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious at most.
There is no a priori reason why propositional attitudes must be access-conscious.
Having meta-cognitive wherewithal is required to know what one's propositional attitudes are.
Russell's paradox does not establish that there are meaningful sentences that are neither true nor false; the relevant expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
The expression "the property of being the set of all sets that aren't members of themselves" picks nothing out.
Tarski's and Russell's type-theory response to the semantic paradoxes is self-defeating.
Anaphoric expressions like "itself" function as bound variables and can be eliminable in extensional contexts.
Mach was wrong to hold that molecules are useful fictions; Einstein showed their existence is required to explain Brownian motion.
Newton's public claims to be purely empirical likely misrepresented his actual methodology for rhetorical reasons.
Every person is to some degree a schizoid-affective psychopath (SAP); differences between the mentally ill and healthy are matters of degree.
To outgrow a belief or desire is not to cease to have it but for it to cease to be operational.
People are organized, non-heaps of thought; thoughts are organized both vertically (hierarchically) and horizontally (laterally).
The mind of the psychologically healthy person is stratified; psychopathology manifests when this stratification breaks down.
A delusion is not a wrong belief but a belief that is right in the wrong way—the vehicle for a correct belief is an infantile and therefore false belief.
Pleasant affects alert us to the presence of certain structural features in music, art, and architecture; unpleasant affects alert us to their absence.
Phenomenologically consecutive mental images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint when considered in isolation from their underlying thought-processes.
The survival instinct is transferred from one's body to one's self as psychological development proceeds.
Initially the psychological superstructure exists to keep the body alive; eventually the body exists to keep the superstructure (self) alive.
To value something is to see it as conducive to the consolidation or enlargement of one's agency.
Hedonistic pleasure is value-free pleasure; accomplishment-based pleasure is not hedonistic.
The object of desire is gratification, but intentions do not aim at gratification—they are judgments about what one must do to have a life embodying certain values.
Athletic ability is cognitive, not somatic in nature; being coordinated consists in one's mind being intelligent in governing one's body.
Moral nihilism and aesthetic nihilism are both false.
Moral nihilism and moral relativism are equivalent doctrines.
The Moore-Hume thesis that you cannot derive an "ought" from an "is" is false.
Moral truths hold in virtue of the same facts as descriptive truths; we can experience facts either as morally antiseptic or as moral truths.
Morally good acts invariably conduce to psychological, biological, or psychobiological welfare.
Emotions are beliefs, though they are not discursive beliefs; they are fundamentally egocentric in nature.
Hume's emotivism—the view that moral ideation is non-judicative sentiment—is wrong.
There is no moral difference without a descriptive difference; the moral supervenes on the descriptive.
Moral intuitions track biological facts about welfare and harm.
One's personhood depends on having values (norms, though not necessarily moral norms).
Psychopathy is a failure to distinguish consequence of excessive rationalization; it involves a collapse of the distinction between self and other.
The acceptance of empiricism is incompatible with the very existence of any attempt to study anything.
If empiricism is correct, nothing or next to nothing can be known about either the external or internal world.
Empiricism leaves the mental as nothing but a series of disjoint ex nihilo obtrusions into an otherwise integrated world.
Paraperception is phenomenology-mediated, real-time conception—the mode by which we perceive language, music, and art.
Categories like rock, tree, and chair are individuated by the counterfactual properties of their instances.
To be a copper bar is to have certain causal properties (conductivity, durability, malleability).
One's survival instinct comes to be transferred from one's body to one's self.
Animals are reflex machines; rational agents are not.
Something that merely reacts is sub-agential; we may call such things "reagents."
Only proposition-aware creatures can have intentions, because intentions are identical with decisions.
Deliberation is nothing other than arriving at a decision.
When an intention is not preceded by deliberation, relevant deliberations have already occurred in the past.
Aristotle and Kant were right that agency is practical rationality and decisions are conclusions of non-theoretical thought-processes.
