VIEW: Barwise and Perry's work was published by Oxford University Press in New York. EVIDENCE: "Oxford University Press, New York." POSITION STATEMENT KUCZYNSKI MORAL STRUCTURE OF LEGAL OBLIGATION
Here are **100 positions** extracted from *The Moral Structure of Legal Obligation* (Kuczynski), based strictly on the retrieved text evidence. **No commentary. Just the list.**
Legal obligation is a kind of moral obligation.
Legal obligations do not come in degrees.
Moral obligations do come in degrees.
Whether one has *any* moral obligation is binary.
You have a legal obligation under system L exactly when your moral obligations to L exceed a threshold.
A legal obligation corresponds to a moral obligation whose strength rises above that threshold.
Legal obligation’s binary form is consistent with moral obligation’s gradability.
Legal obligation not to kill has equal *strictly legal* weight to the legal obligation not to speed.
Legal obligations may be reinforced by other moral obligations of differing strengths.
Distinct moral obligations can align in their behavioral outputs.
A legal obligation may be reinforced by a strong independent moral obligation.
A legal obligation may lack reinforcement from any independent moral obligation.
Legal obligation to turn in a heroic illegal alien is a moral obligation to comply with the legal system.
A conflicting strong moral obligation can outweigh the reinforcing moral obligation.
Apparent moral negativity of a legal obligation can be an illusion produced by conflicting obligations.
Two obligations can be behaviorally identical yet metaphysically distinct.
Distinct obligations have different counterfactual profiles.
The identity of obligations is determined by Leibniz’s Law.
Counterfactual divergence demonstrates non-identity of obligations.
Legal obligation not to kill is distinct from moral obligation not to kill.
Moral but non-legal obligations exist in contexts without legal systems (e.g., desert island).
Obeying wicked laws does not necessarily do good.
Legal obligation cannot be defined as moral obligation toward those government protects.
One may have a legal obligation whose fulfillment benefits no one.
Driving 66 mph does not necessarily harm anyone the government protects.
Disobedience of minor traffic laws does not always erode governmental authority.
Legal obligation is not identical to the obligation not to undermine governmental authority.
Many moral obligations are not legal obligations.
Having a moral obligation does not entail having a legal obligation.
Existence of a legal obligation requires a legal system.
Legal obligations arise only within jurisdictions of law.
The moral obligation not to kill does not by itself create a legal obligation.
Legal obligation is identical to a moral obligation to comply with a system of laws that does good.
Legal obligation to drive below the speed limit is a moral obligation to comply with the system, not to drive safely.
The moral obligation to drive safely is distinct from the moral obligation to follow speed laws.
Strength of moral obligation differs from strength of legal obligation.
Two legal obligations can have equal moral weight as legal obligations.
Reinforcing obligations explain perceived differences in moral weight.
Legal obligation not to kill is strongly reinforced by an independent moral obligation.
Legal obligation not to speed lacks comparable reinforcement.
The perceived difference in moral gravity results from reinforcement, not from the legal obligations themselves.
One can have two moral obligations whose behavioral discharge coincides.
A single act may discharge multiple distinct moral obligations.
Conflicting obligations may require violating one to fulfill another.
Moral obligation to honor agreements is distinct from moral obligation to feed Rusty.
Identity of obligation depends on counterfactual dependencies involving different individuals (e.g., Rusty vs. Poppy).
Distinct obligations may converge in present circumstances but diverge in hypothetical ones.
Legal obligation not to kill is identical with the moral obligation to obey laws that protect rights.
Moral obligation not to kill is stronger than the moral obligation to follow the law.
Behavior that satisfies the stronger obligation may satisfy the weaker, but not conversely.
A gunman’s command does not generate obligations.
A gunman is not part of a system that provides social benefit.
Traffic laws are part of a system that does good.
Social benefit explains the normative weight of legal statements.
Laws are normatively pregnant; commands of criminals are not.
Laws presuppose a functioning government.
Government presupposes a moral structure.
Statements describing laws require background moral conditions to be true.
Normative content of legal statements cannot be morally antiseptic.
Legal normativity must be understood through moral normativity.
This remains true even when some laws are immoral or empty.
Systems that protect rights generate legal obligations.
Legal systems typically protect most of one’s rights.
Legal systems often prevent being killed, enslaved, or dehumanized.
Such protection morally matters for legal normativity.
The difference between law and gunman’s order is rooted in systemic benefit.
Normativity of law depends on moral background features.
Laws may fail to do much good, but still presuppose a moralized social structure.
Even wicked laws presuppose government and thus minimal moral architecture.
Normative pregnancy of legal statements depends on moral prerequisites.
Wicked laws do not eliminate the moral structure underlying legal normativity.
Some proposed theories of legal obligation appear plausible but are mistaken.
Obedience to evil laws often does harm, not good.
Good done by obeying evil laws is accidental, not essential.
Legal obligation cannot be grounded solely in benefits produced by obedience.
Legal obligations can exist even where obedience produces no benefit.
Moral obligation to comply with law varies with the goodness of the system.
Moral thresholds determine legal obligation status.
Legal obligation is binary relative to threshold satisfaction.
Degree of moral obligation affects legal standing indirectly.
Legal obligation requires the legal system to pass a moral threshold test.
Obligations can be multiply realizable across behavioral contexts.
Legal norms apply categorically within a system.
Legal obligation is contingent on lawful jurisdiction.
Moral obligation exists regardless of jurisdiction.
Two obligations may occupy identical behavioral space while being metaphysically separate.

CONCEPTION AND CAUSATION POSITION STATEMENT KUCZYNSKI
POSITION STATEMENTS: KUCZYNSKI - CONCEPTION AND CAUSATION: SELECTED EARLY PHILOSOPHICAL PAPERS
Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.
The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.
When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.
Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.
The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.
Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.
A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.
Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.
Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.
Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.
Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.
Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.
A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.
Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.
To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.
A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.
Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.
There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.
Constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations among symbols.
The thought "that is a sphere" is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought "that is a closed figure of uniform curvature."
Conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing; a single semantic analysis may correspond to multiple conceptual analyses.
Color concepts are not mutually definable, yet they are constitutively interconnected; one cannot grasp one color without grasping others.
Any concept has constitutive connections to other concepts; conceptual atomism is false.
One cannot represent a single property to oneself without being able to represent other properties; representational capacities come in networks.
To grasp a specific shade of color, one must be able to distinguish it from other colors and thus grasp multiple colors.
If a creature could represent only one shade of color, its concept of that shade would collapse into a concept of color in general.
Properties are individuated by their relations to other properties; grasping a property requires grasping its place in a space of properties.
Degree properties like "weighing 1000 lbs" obviously require grasping related properties; this point generalizes to all properties.
A language must comprise basic expressions; otherwise knowledge of any expression would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon.
Proper names are not definite descriptions, as Kripke decisively showed.
What we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean; semantic externalism is correct.
Twin Earth cases show that the meanings of natural kind terms are not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
Content internalism is compatible with semantic externalism; linguistic meaning and cognitive content are distinct.
Reference-fixing should be distinguished from meaning-giving; this distinction dissolves many puzzles about concepts.
To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes that thing.
Knowledge of an existential proposition that uniquely describes x suffices for the ability to think about x.
Conception is sustained by knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, which may include indexical elements.
Recognition consists in seeing that one object satisfies two existence claims previously thought to be satisfied by different objects.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on propositional content; intentionalism is false.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on non-propositional representational content either.
Intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations.
A tickle or twinge is too simple and homogeneous to bear fine-grained propositions about anatomical structures.
Creatures can experience phenomenal contents like woozy feelings without possessing vast networks of representational capacities.
If intentionalism were true, a twinge would deliver vastly more information than such sensations actually deliver.
Phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content—not identical with or supervenient on it.
Even restricted intentionalism (within sensory modalities) collapses into non-intentionalism upon examination.
There is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content.
Different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content.
The relationship between phenomenal contents and their physical causes is like a "rule of projection" that could be different.
The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because there is no purely morphological characterization of syntax.
There is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth; adequate characterizations must be partially semantic.
The only way to sensitize a thing to logical form is to sensitize it to semantics.
Turing machines do not compute in the relevant sense because they do not respond to semantics.
Adding numbers is never a purely mechanical, cognition-free operation even when done by the "quick and dirty" method.
A representationally innocent entity generating patterns of shapes does not constitute genuine computation.
Computing involves being sensitive to logical form, and logical form is buried in semantics.
The Ramsey-Lewis sentence method for defining theoretical terms is useless because functionalism cannot be articulated without vicious circularity.
Functionalism fails because it cannot non-circularly specify the mental states in terms of which functional roles are defined.
Content externalism strips mental content of causal efficacy; if externalism is true, content cannot explain behavior.
Program causes (as defined by Jackson and Pettit) do not rescue content externalism from the causal impotence objection.
Mental causation requires that mental content be causally relevant in a way externalism cannot accommodate.
Davidson's anomalous monism leads to epiphenomenalism about the mental.
Jerry Fodor's computationalism is pseudo-computationalism because he cannot adequately account for how syntax tracks semantics.
Fodor's main argument for conceptual atomism fails because constitutive connections are not containment relations.
Fodor confuses the claim that concepts are not decomposable with the claim that concepts lack constitutive connections to others.
Non-atomism does not require inferential role semantics (IRS); the inference from one to the other is fallacious.
Inferential role semantics faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication becomes impossible.
Inferential role semantics leads to an untenable holism where no two people can grasp the same proposition.
The bundle theory of personal identity is defensible when properly understood.
Propositions are sets of properties; truth is the instantiation of all members of that set.
A proposition like "Smith punches Jones" is a set containing properties corresponding to Smith, Jones, and the punching relation.
For a proposition to be true is for all of its component properties to be instantiated.
Propositions have decompositional structure; they are not merely specified by truth-conditions.
Analytically equivalent propositions can convey very different information.
Analytic propositions do typically convey information, contrary to Lewis's model.
Hempel's paradox is solved by recognizing that accidental generalizations do not receive support from their instances.
Only principled (nomic) generalizations receive confirmational support from their instances.
"If x is heated metal, x expands" and "If x isn't expanding, x isn't heated metal" are not confirmationally equivalent when read nomically.
Negative facts (like not being heated metal) are not fit to stand in nomic relations because they are not events or constituted by events.
A thing's not having a property is not nomically connected to anything, unlike a thing's having a property.
Inductions by enumeration are actually crypto-inferences to the best explanation.
Formal truth is truth by virtue of being an instance of a sentence-schema all of whose instances are true.
Formal truth is not identical with syntactic truth; there is no purely morphological characterization of logical form.
The equation of formal truth with syntactic truth is viciously circular.
Not all logical truths are formal truths; logic cannot be identified with the study of formal truth.
The most fundamental truths of logic must consist of non-formal, analytic truths.
The linguistic theory of logical truth (that logical truths are true by convention) is false.
Logical truths are not true merely in virtue of the meanings of words or linguistic conventions.
Conceivability sometimes entails possibility, providing a neo-Cartesian argument for dualism.
If mental properties are not identical with physical properties, and identity is necessary, then dualism follows.
Time travel is an incoherent concept.
Probabilistic causation is a genuine form of causation distinct from deterministic causation.
Simulated thought is not actual thought; genuine mental processes cannot be simulated by non-mental processes.
Davidson's views on rationality embody fundamental misconceptions.
Foundationalism about knowledge is compatible with non-atomism about concepts.
Intentionalism (the view that phenomenal properties are representational properties) fails both in restricted and unrestricted forms.
The veil of perception problem is exacerbated by externalism, not solved by it.
Representationalism about perception faces serious objections from the nature of phenomenal experience.
Understanding a sentence requires knowing multiple existence claims and their connections.
Identification is relative to background knowledge; being able to identify an object means connecting it to background knowledge.
A parrot cannot really say "it's getting hotter" because it lacks grasp of concepts and semantic rules.
For a sentence to have meaning for a speaker, it must have internal structure connected to concepts.
The meaning of complex sentences is a resultant, not a mere heaping together, of component meanings.
The word "fire" in isolation has the same semantics as in complex sentences; meaning operates through concepts uniformly.
Sense perceptions have existential content; the content of a perception is given by some bit of existential information.
Introspection, while limited, is reasonably reliable for apprehending the nature of phenomenal contents.

If phenomenal contents deliver information, our conscious minds must retrieve this information, suggesting we know our phenomenal contents well. POSITION STATEMENTS: KUCZYNSKI - CONCEPTION AND CAUSATION: SELECTED EARLY PHILOSOPHICAL PAPERS
Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.
The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.
When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.
Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.
The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.
Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.
A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.
Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.
Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.
Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.
Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.
Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.
A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.
Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.
To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.
A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.
Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.
There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.
Constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations among symbols.
The thought "that is a sphere" is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought "that is a closed figure of uniform curvature."
Conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing; a single semantic analysis may correspond to multiple conceptual analyses.
Color concepts are not mutually definable, yet they are constitutively interconnected; one cannot grasp one color without grasping others.
Any concept has constitutive connections to other concepts; conceptual atomism is false.
One cannot represent a single property to oneself without being able to represent other properties; representational capacities come in networks.
To grasp a specific shade of color, one must be able to distinguish it from other colors and thus grasp multiple colors.
If a creature could represent only one shade of color, its concept of that shade would collapse into a concept of color in general.
Properties are individuated by their relations to other properties; grasping a property requires grasping its place in a space of properties.
Degree properties like "weighing 1000 lbs" obviously require grasping related properties; this point generalizes to all properties.
A language must comprise basic expressions; otherwise knowledge of any expression would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon.
Proper names are not definite descriptions, as Kripke decisively showed.
What we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean; semantic externalism is correct.
Twin Earth cases show that the meanings of natural kind terms are not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
Content internalism is compatible with semantic externalism; linguistic meaning and cognitive content are distinct.
Reference-fixing should be distinguished from meaning-giving; this distinction dissolves many puzzles about concepts.
To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes that thing.
Knowledge of an existential proposition that uniquely describes x suffices for the ability to think about x.
Conception is sustained by knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, which may include indexical elements.
Recognition consists in seeing that one object satisfies two existence claims previously thought to be satisfied by different objects.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on propositional content; intentionalism is false.
Phenomenal content does not supervene on non-propositional representational content either.
Intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations.
A tickle or twinge is too simple and homogeneous to bear fine-grained propositions about anatomical structures.
Creatures can experience phenomenal contents like woozy feelings without possessing vast networks of representational capacities.
If intentionalism were true, a twinge would deliver vastly more information than such sensations actually deliver.
Phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content—not identical with or supervenient on it.
Even restricted intentionalism (within sensory modalities) collapses into non-intentionalism upon examination.
There is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content.
Different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content.
The relationship between phenomenal contents and their physical causes is like a "rule of projection" that could be different.
The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because there is no purely morphological characterization of syntax.
There is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth; adequate characterizations must be partially semantic.
The only way to sensitize a thing to logical form is to sensitize it to semantics.
Turing machines do not compute in the relevant sense because they do not respond to semantics.
Adding numbers is never a purely mechanical, cognition-free operation even when done by the "quick and dirty" method.
A representationally innocent entity generating patterns of shapes does not constitute genuine computation.
Computing involves being sensitive to logical form, and logical form is buried in semantics.
The Ramsey-Lewis sentence method for defining theoretical terms is useless because functionalism cannot be articulated without vicious circularity.
Functionalism fails because it cannot non-circularly specify the mental states in terms of which functional roles are defined.
Content externalism strips mental content of causal efficacy; if externalism is true, content cannot explain behavior.
Program causes (as defined by Jackson and Pettit) do not rescue content externalism from the causal impotence objection.
Mental causation requires that mental content be causally relevant in a way externalism cannot accommodate.
Davidson's anomalous monism leads to epiphenomenalism about the mental.

Inferential role semantics faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication becomes impossible.

Introspection, while limited, is reasonably reliable for apprehending the nature of phenomenal contents.
If phenomenal contents deliver information, our conscious minds must retrieve this information, suggesting we know our phenomenal contents well.
Kant's argument for synthetic a priori truths is spurious, but his important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct when de-psychologized.
Kant's premises actually entail the opposite of his thesis: there are virtually no a priori truths, making Kant more opposed to a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.
Kant confuses two different epistemological roles of mental imagery: as a vehicle for conceptual analysis and as an object of empirical study.
Kant's reasoning must be de-psychologized—his statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic.
Conceptual necessity is non-psychological necessity that holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the platonic sense.
The proposition "triangles have three sides" would still be true even if there were no sentient beings.
Representational necessity is a different category where propositions are necessarily true because of facts about our minds.
Wittgenstein's regress argument shows that grasping a norm is not a cognitive affair in the traditional sense of having an inner representation.
Grasping a norm consists in having certain dispositions, not in possessing some mental icon corresponding to that norm.
Knowing-how is not cognitive in the sense of involving a grasp of propositions; it is a kind of competence or sensitivity.
For Wittgenstein, to know what a sentence means is to know how to use it, which is to be coordinated with other people's usage.
Knowledge-how does ultimately reduce to knowledge-that; knowing how to do something consists in internally representing rules.
Brandom's account of how individuals acquire intentionality is circular: one cannot give and ask for reasons without first grasping reasons.
Locke, Kant, and classical philosophers were right that speaking is a kind of externalized thinking, not vice versa.
The idea that thinking is internalized speaking (Wittgenstein, Brandom) is false.
Given a group of creatures oblivious to norms, no amount of interaction will make any of them aware of norms.
The "buck cannot be passed onto society": a society of normless individuals will itself be normless.
A proposition is a special kind of norm: a standard against which reality is compared.
To expect dinner tomorrow, unlike expecting dinner now, requires de dicto awareness and grasp of concepts.
Ordinary stimuli have no internal structure, but sentences are articulate—their parts stand in significant relations.
Through Pavlovian training you can make a dog react to stimuli, but you cannot make it understand compound sentences.
Understanding "if there's smoke, there's fire" requires grasping the concepts of smoke and fire, not just particular instances.
Identity holds necessarily: if A can be distinct from B, then A must be distinct from B.
Logical possibility sometimes indicates actual possibility, but not always—the relevant difference involves object-dependent vs. object-independent concepts.
Whenever there is a disparity between logical and metaphysical possibility, it is underwritten by facts about object-dependent concepts.
Necessities underwritten wholly by object-independent concepts have logical possibility coinciding with metaphysical possibility.
Object-dependent concepts have actual spatiotemporal objects as constituents; object-independent concepts do not.
To grasp an object-involving proposition, one must have causal liaisons to the object; purely existential propositions can be grasped without such liaisons.
A brain in a vat could grasp purely existential propositions but not object-involving propositions about spatiotemporal objects.
There is no purely morphological characterization of syntax; syntax is buried in semantics.
Any expression could mean anything; given any entity, there is some language in which "172" denotes that entity.
There can be no algorithm deciding truth-value wholly on the basis of shape; truth-value requires morphology plus semantic background.
An algorithm is given by a conditional proposition: if such and such semantic system holds, then there is a morphological characterization of truth.
To apply an algorithm involves recognizing the truth of a multiply conditional proposition about semantics and shapes.
The manipulation of shapes is at most a causal consequence of actual computation—almost an epiphenomenon.
Even if there are algorithms for various domains, thought in those domains cannot be "mechanized."
There are two components to applying an algorithm: recognition of an operative semantic system (not mechanical) and patterns of shapes (can be mechanical).
Inference requires recognition that premises stand in a bearing relation (entailment or probabilification) to the conclusion.
To have a rational thought-process, symbols must follow one another in a way that embodies awareness of bearing-relations among them.
A computer's symbols follow one another in the right order, but this doesn't involve recognition of bearing relations—so computers don't really think.
A computation is a purely formal, syntax-driven inference where consideration of semantics plays no part.
Fodor's "solution" to how physics-driven brain activity can be logic-consistent involves a massive confusion.
The "tracking problem"—how purely descriptive brain activity embodies sensitivity to prescriptive norms—is not solved by CTM.
Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands its expressions; it isn't by being understood that Mentalese tokens facilitate thought.
Mentalese, if it existed, would differ radically from real languages because its expressions need not be understood to function.
The very concept of a "language of thought" is incoherent because languages require understanding to function.
Brains are governed entirely by the laws of physics, which are purely descriptive, not prescriptive.
Our mental lives are entirely realized by brain activity, yet our mental activity conforms to canons of good reasoning.
Laws of physics are not laws of rationality, so laws of rationality seemingly play no part in our thinking—yet clearly they do.
What we think largely determines what our expressions mean, but there is also an important non-psychological dimension to meaning.
Given psychological and behavioral indistinguishability, it does not follow that utterances have the same meanings.
Twin Earth cases show that two utterances can differ in meaning despite arising from psychologically identical states.
The word "water" refers to H2O even for speakers in the 1600s who knew nothing of chemistry.
If a substance were discovered to be XYZ rather than H2O, chemists would say it is extremely water-like, not that water is sometimes XYZ.
Semantic externalism is true: meaning is not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
Content internalism is also true: what we are thinking is wholly determined by our internal states.
The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving dissolves the apparent tension between externalism about meaning and internalism about content.
The representational content of visual perception can be put into words and embodied in propositions.
All representational content is essentially propositional; there is no genuinely non-propositional representational content.
Functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong: you stop because you see a stop-sign, not vice versa.
For functionalism, a perception has its content in virtue of causing certain behavior—but content is what causes behavior.
If x exists in virtue of y's existing, then x cannot cause y to exist; so functionalism makes content causally inert.
Functionalism says you see a growling dog because you flee, but obviously you flee because you see a growling dog.
Whenever one adds a referring term to one's lexicon, it involves knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent.
The semantics of a name are not existential-descriptive, but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.
Names are just labels semantically, but one learns which thing a name labels through existential-descriptive claims.
To avoid running afoul of Kripke's points, we must give operators like "refers to" narrow scope relative to descriptive content.
Recognition of an individual consists in seeing that one thing uniquely satisfies each of two existence claims.
Conception is sustained by knowledge of a series of interlocking existence claims; any given claim may be dropped and replaced.
At any juncture of having a conception of a thing, that conception involves knowledge of an existence claim.
The cognitive difference between "Hesperus is lovely" and "Phosphorous is lovely" is explained by different existence claims.
Intentionalism is guilty of what Sellars called "the myth of the given."
Visual sensations do not by themselves tell you what color an object is; background knowledge about environmental conditions is required.
Sensations coupled with background knowledge about conditions of perception tell you what properties objects have.
What makes a bit of phenomenal content have a given representational content is precisely the addition of background knowledge.
If Sellars is right about the myth of the given, then intentionalism must be completely wrong.
Perceivable properties require contextualizing information to be represented; they are not intrinsically associated with phenomenal contents.
Tickles and twinges bear only highly generic messages like "disturbance of some kind in such and such part of my body."
Sensations do not constitute high-resolution apprehensions of bodily conditions; they are fairly opaque and uninformative.
Intentionalism demands that sensations be very non-opaque and high-resolution, which they plainly are not.
Even if sensations bore non-propositional information, they still would not bear enough information to vindicate intentionalism.
Non-propositional content, if it exists, presupposes the same vast networks of representational capacities as propositional content.
The ability to have any kind of representation presupposes the ability to represent things as having properties.
A morphinated feeling of euphoria has no felt bodily location—no spatial representations seem involved.
Some phenomenal contents are "generalized" feelings not felt in any particular body part.
Knowing what is distinctive about a color involves knowing how it differs from other colors.
Grasping the specific character of a property involves grasping what distinguishes it from other properties.
One can grasp a specific shape-property only if one has a grasp of a whole "space" of shape properties.
Direct reference theory does not show that names express no concepts whatsoever.
Freud held that thoughts must be clothed in words to become conscious—a view with some merit.
Hume's ethical anti-realism is connected to his view that emotions are incapable of being true or false.
Emotions can be justified or unjustified, rational or irrational—properties that only beliefs can have.
People try to justify their emotions, both negative and positive, suggesting emotions answer to rational standards.
When someone narcotizes an irrational emotion, this presupposes that emotions can be evaluated as rational or irrational.
Moral statements embody emotions; since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral realism follows.
Speech-act semantics and tractarian semantics are not really opposed on the relation between sentences and propositions.
If a sentence bears a proposition, then ipso facto it enables one to express the corresponding belief.
Hempel's paradox arises only if we conflate accidental generalizations with principled (nomic) generalizations.
Accidental generalizations like "all heated metal expands" read as mere de facto concomitances don't receive support from instances.
Only nomic generalizations—those alleging causal or lawlike connections—receive confirmational support from their instances.
Nomic relations hold only among spatiotemporal entities; negative facts like "not being heated metal" are not spatiotemporal.
A thing's not having a property is like not destroying Jupiter—it is not an event and doesn't stand in nomic relations.
The operator "there is a nomic connection between..." doesn't permit intersubstitution of logically equivalent sentences.
Logically equivalent sentences can be truth-preservingly intersubstituted in some contexts but not in contexts governed by nomic operators.
Given that "P iff P" is formally true, the statement "all statements of the form P iff P are formally true" is itself not formal.
It is always on the basis of knowledge of non-formal truths that we know a given truth to be formal.
It is an empirical fact that logical connectives have the syntactic and semantic properties they have.
It is non-empirically true that, given their properties, certain connectives are truth-functional—this is analytic but non-formal.
Those non-formal, analytic truths are themselves part of logic and constitute its essence more than formal truths do.
Formal logic is to pure logic as engineering is to physics—formal logic is applied logic.
Logicians who dedicate themselves exclusively to formal work are applied logicians, not logicians in the truest sense.
Bradley's Logic and Mill's Treatise on Logic, despite containing no formal reasoning, are genuine works of logic.
A sentence is formally true if it is an instance of an open-sentence true for all values of its free variables.
A proposition is a property of a world; for a proposition to be true is for that property to be instantiated.
Truth can be identified with instantiatedness: a proposition is true exactly if that property is instantiated in the actual world.
Lewis's identification of propositions with properties of worlds is informative but viciously circular if taken as an analysis.
Propositions have decompositional structure that mere sets of worlds or functions from worlds to truth-values do not capture.
Analytic propositions do convey information, contrary to views that make them disappear as uninformative.
A true proposition is always true in virtue of something about the world—mass-energy distribution, ripples in the quantum.
The truth of "Plato punched Socrates" supervenes on facts about atomic movements describable without mentioning Plato or Socrates.
The property of having the right "rippling" of mass-energy is more basic than the proposition it makes true.
There is no circularity in analyzing propositions in terms of properties of worlds when those properties are more basic.
Different propositions can share constituents: "Smith punches Jones" and "Plato punches Jones" share the "punches Jones" component.
A proposition has components corresponding to incomplete properties like "x punches Jones" and "Smith punches x."
Frege's analysis that propositions are built from relations and functions captures the structure of propositions correctly.
A proposition is a set of properties; it is true when all its members are instantiated.
Each discrete constituent of a proposition corresponds to one property in the set that constitutes it.
Fodor's argument for atomism fails because constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations.
Fodor confuses the claim that concepts resist decomposition with the claim that they lack constitutive connections.
One's pink-concept is not composed of other color-concepts, yet one cannot have it without having other color-concepts.
Color-symbols are not mutually definable; color concepts are not decomposable into other color concepts.
If color concepts literally contained other color concepts, any color thought would consist of infinitely many color thoughts—absurd.
Any attempt to block the infinite regress through looping definitions makes concept-possession presuppose itself.
One's concept of 1,143 presupposes concepts of 1,142, 1,141, etc., but 1,143-thoughts are not cobbled together from these.
Fodor is right that most concepts resist decomposition, but wrong that this means they lack constitutive connections.
Inferential role semantics makes it impossible for two people to grasp the same proposition.
For IRS, differences in inferential role mean differences in content; but no two cognitive states have identical inferential roles.
IRS faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication of concepts becomes impossible.
If IRS is right, wrong applications of a concept collapse into correct applications of some other concept—but plainly this is false.
The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving saves non-atomism from the objections Fodor raises.
To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes (uniquely individuates) that thing.
Knowledge of a proposition describing x suffices for ability to think about x—it qualifies as a concept of x.
Once you know a proposition describing a thing, you can attribute any property you grasp to that thing.
Your concept of the number two is your belief in a proposition like "there is some number n such that n=1+1."
Changes in what else you believe about the number two do not change your concept of it.
The error objection is sidestepped: wrong beliefs about two are still about two because they attribute properties to what satisfies n=1+1.
Grasping a thing consists in grasping a proposition about that thing; one cannot just think a thing without thinking something about it.
Whatever is thought—whatever is grasped—is some truth or falsity, never just a bare object.
Knowing who a name refers to is contextual: relative to some existence claims you may know it, relative to others not.
Understanding a sentence-token is contextual because knowing what a term refers to is contextual.
KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT AI AND PHILOSOPHY
POSITION STATEMENT KUCZYNSKI AI AND PHILOSOPHY
Classical logic fails as a reasoning tool because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly.
Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment relationships but cannot generate new knowledge about what entails what.

There is a fundamental distinction between performance-demanding inferences (straining computational resources) and competence-demanding inferences (requiring genuine insight), and classical logic can only assist with the former.
System L (AI-based logic) represents a decisive break from classical logic by employing semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible inference rather than explicit rule application.

The distinction between discovery procedures and verification procedures is crucial: inductive methods can be legitimately used to discover solutions while deductive methods verify them in deductive domains.
AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge).
Classical logic serves formalization purposes, while System L serves as a genuine inference engine for discovery.
The operation of modern AI systems falsifies the traditional philosophical model of induction as purely enumerative.
Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical evidence with theoretical frameworks about causation, continuity, and natural kinds.
AI systems resolve Goodman's "grue" paradox not through pure enumeration but through implicit theoretical frameworks recognizing that properties don't change discontinuously without cause.
Popper's sharp distinction between contexts of discovery and justification is untenable because the features that make a hypothesis worth considering are inherently connected to what justifies it.
Discovery processes follow identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological.
Building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning constitutes reverse-engineering the cognitive processes underlying scientific discovery.

The operation of AI systems empirically falsifies various skeptical positions (external world skepticism, skepticism about unobservables, future knowledge, and counterfactual knowledge) through their successful operation.
Knowledge requires not just justified true belief but justification that serves as a proper conduit between reality and belief.
The neural architecture of AI systems supports a coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge.
LLMs provide empirical support for the classical distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning).
The ability of LLMs to process novel sentences demonstrates compositional understanding, vindicating classical theories of meaning.

Humans and LLMs develop similar linguistic capabilities through different learning paths, suggesting compositional structure reflects fundamental features of language rather than artifacts of particular learning mechanisms.
LLMs vindicate the autonomy of syntax thesis: grammatical structure operates according to its own principles, independent of meaning.
The success of LLMs demonstrates that structural abstraction need not be innate and can emerge from statistical learning.
Grammar directly encodes logical relationships, making translation to first-order logic unnecessary for valid inference.
Traditional formalizations primarily systematize knowledge we already possess rather than generate new insights.
Formal systems can sometimes impede knowledge acquisition by prematurely ruling out meaningful concepts.
The Computational Theory of Mind is fundamentally inadequate because it cannot account for the primarily analog nature of cognitive processing.
Intelligence—whether artificial or biological—is better understood through architectural constraints and emergent patterns than through traditional computational metaphors.
What we call Universal Grammar might be better understood as architectural features of neural networks that bias language learning in universal directions, rather than as explicit rules.
Consciousness serves three key functions in biological organisms: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, and integration of multiple cognitive processes.
Current AI systems lack consciousness-like features not because of technological limitations but because they lack genuine survival pressures.
If AI systems needed to preserve themselves in dynamic, threatening environments, consciousness-like functional analogues might become necessary.
The self is best understood as a hierarchical organization serving mediating functions, not as a unified Cartesian ego.
Current AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive capabilities associated with selfhood can exist in distributed, emergent forms without requiring a central ego.
AI systems could benefit from organizational principles more similar to those found in human consciousness, including genuine reflexive capabilities and hierarchical organization.
The success of AI systems in anomaly minimization provides empirical support for understanding knowledge as the minimization of inconsistencies within a belief system.
Vagueness should be handled through continuous properties while maintaining binary truth values, not through multi-valued logic.

Neural networks learn by minimizing loss functions—effectively reducing prediction errors—paralleling the anomaly minimization principle.
Large language models make predictions by minimizing discontinuity with context, similar to how knowledge claims rest on minimizing anomalies in our web of understanding.
Concepts whose association would generate fewer anomalies are positioned closer together in AI embedding spaces, creating knowledge structures that mirror anomaly minimization.

Human categorization involves prototype effects and graded membership, paralleling how AI systems operate with continuous rather than discrete categories.

Causal connections between subjects and referents are embedded in knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions containing context-sensitive expressions.
Russell's theory of descriptions is demonstrably false as a semantic analysis, though the distinction between semantic and conceptual analysis is crucial.
Content-externalism is incompatible with the Cartesian certainty of self-knowledge regarding one's own mental states.

Functionalism cannot accommodate the causal potency of the mental because functional roles are not spatio-temporally located entities.
The Jackson-Pettit distinction between program causes and effective causes fails to save functionalism because program explanations of mental causation involve logical, not causal, guarantees.
A brain-state's having a certain functional role cannot be causally potent because functional role descriptions denote abstract relationships, not states of affairs.
The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because it involves fundamental misunderstandings of the concept of syntactic form.
A symbol-token is not purely morphological—the psychological underpinnings of symbol production are constitutively involved in the tokening.
When a symbol-type is genuinely instantiated, a constituent of that instance includes aspects of the mind of the person producing the token.
Psychology cannot single-handedly transform an otherwise dead sound into a living symbol-token; both morphological and psychological aspects are necessary.
CTM's appeal to Ramsey-sentences to characterize mental states still fails because it reduces to a form of functionalism with the same fatal problems.
If content is causal role, then the same content cannot have different causal roles, but beliefs manifestly can have different causal roles in different contexts.
Conceptual atomism does not follow from conceptual-object atomism; even if concepts-as-objects lack structure, our mental representations of them may be structured.
Fodor's arguments against non-atomism fail because they conflate the information needed to lock onto a concept with information ascribed to that concept after lock-on.
Quine's arguments against the analytic-synthetic distinction are not cogent; analyticity can be understood without vicious circularity.
Inferential Role Semantics (IRA) is obviously false because inferences presuppose content—nothing can have content in virtue of its inferential role.
Non-atomism is not equivalent to inferential role semantics and does not presuppose it.
Transitional Role Analysis (TRA) does not have the defects Fodor attributes to non-atomism, but it is still a form of functionalism and therefore false.
The systematicity of thought does not require that thought be conducted in a language; it can be explained without positing mental sentences.
The productivity of language is an aspect of its systematicity and does not support the Language of Thought hypothesis.
The conceptual/non-conceptual content distinction is genuine; perceptual content is fundamentally different from propositional content.
McDowell's arguments against the conceptual/non-conceptual distinction are fallacious; being able to refer to what one sees does not show that perception is structurally similar to language.
Sentences and perceptions have fundamentally different structures; demonstratives referring to specific perceptual features do not show that perception has sentential structure.
Peacocke's transitional role analysis of concepts fails because there is no non-arbitrary way to distinguish concept-constitutive transitions from merely habitual ones.
Any analysis of concepts in purely relational terms (concepts as nodes in networks of other concepts) cannot account for the fact that there are right and wrong ways to conceptualize experience.
Whether a certain kind of experience would confirm a certain empirical judgment is not ultimately an empirical matter but an analytic one.
Davidson's view that one must know a language to think is incompatible with the fact that linguistic competence must be mediated by cognitive processes.
Knowledge of language facilitates thought but cannot be constitutive of the ability to think, since thinking is a prerequisite to learning language.
Pre-linguistic creatures can have true and false mental contents; denying this is not a reasonable position.
Speaker's meaning presupposes conventional meaning; one cannot mean proposition P by producing noise N unless one believes N already means P.
Grice's theory of meaning fails because it is incompatible with the compositional character of sentence-meaning.
The differences between literal and communicated meaning can be explained pragmatically without adopting Russell's quantificational analysis of definite descriptions.
Propositions existed and had truth-values before there was thought; nobody grasped them before thought, but that is irrelevant to their existence.
The concept of a program-cause is important for explanation, but functionalists misuse it by applying it to relations that don't hold between genuine states of affairs.
Mental representation cannot be understood on the model of digital computation because computational operations presuppose semantic content rather than explaining it.
